{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18306,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ceriporia spissa, a type of polypore fungus, thrives in moist environments. Unlike traditional plants, it does not require direct watering. Instead, maintaining a humid environment is essential. Ensure that its habitat has enough moisture by occasionally misting or placing it in a naturally damp area, such as near a water source or within a terrarium. Avoid overwatering, as Ceriporia spissa relies on ambient humidity more than direct water application. Monitoring the surrounding humidity and ensuring it doesn’t dry out is key to maintaining healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ceriporia spissa does not require direct sunlight and actually thrives in shaded or low-light conditions. It naturally grows on decaying wood, often found in forested environments where sunlight is dappled through the canopy. Placing this fungus in indirect light is sufficient for its growth. Too much direct sunlight can dry it out and detrimentally affect its development. Maintaining a stable, low-light environment will encourage healthy growth and reproduction, mimicking its natural habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As Ceriporia spissa is a fungus, it does not require traditional pruning. However, managing its environment involves removing any decaying plant matter or materials where it might be growing to prevent overgrowth and maintain harmony in its environment. You might want to carefully cut back some of its spread if it becomes too expansive. Always handle with care, as fungal structures can be delicate. Wearing gloves is advisable to avoid transferring oils or contaminants that might affect its growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Ceriporia spissa is a species of fungus in the Phanerochaetaceae family. It is a plant pathogen.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Ceriporia spissa"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16802,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phlomis tuberosa prefers soil that is moderately dry to slightly moist, making it relatively drought-tolerant once established. It is important not to overwater this plant as it can lead to root rot. Water deeply but infrequently to encourage the roots to grow deep into the soil. It’s generally sufficient to water every 7-10 days during the growing season, especially if rainfall is scarce. During the winter, reduce watering further, as the plant enters dormancy and requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlomis tuberosa thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. This exposure ensures robust growth and vibrant flowering. It can also tolerate partial shade, but flowering might be less prolific in lower light conditions. When planting Phlomis tuberosa, choose a location that receives ample sunlight throughout the day. In regions with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade can help prevent the foliage from scorching but should not significantly limit light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Phlomis tuberosa is mainly done to promote healthy growth and to maintain a neat appearance. In late winter or early spring, remove any dead or damaged stems to prepare the plant for the growing season. After flowering, prune back the spent flower stalks to encourage new blooms and to prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. It's also beneficial to remove any yellowing or diseased leaves whenever noticed. Light pruning throughout the growing season can help maintain shape and prevent unwanted self-seeding."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Phlomoides tuberosa is a perennial flowering plant in the family Lamiaceae native to China, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia, Russia; SW Asia and Europe. Enlarged, tuberous roots give rise to erect stems to 150 cm bearing purple-red flowers.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Phlomis tuberosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16401,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Facelis retusa, commonly known as small cudweed, requires minimal watering. It is adapted to dry environments and prefers well-drained soil. During its growing season, water the plant only when the soil feels dry to the touch, usually every 10 to 14 days, depending on humidity and temperature. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so ensure the container or garden bed has good drainage. In dormancy, especially during the cooler seasons, reduce watering frequency significantly. Always allow the soil to dry out between waterings to mimic its natural arid habitat conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Facelis retusa thrives in full sun conditions, mimicking its native habitat. It should be placed in a location where it can receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms. This plant is highly adaptable to bright, open environments and prefers warm temperatures. If grown indoors, situate it near a south-facing window or provide supplemental lighting. Be cautious with extreme heat; in peak summer, some afternoon shading might protect it from scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Facelis retusa is generally minimal due to its small, compact nature. Regularly remove dead or yellowing leaves to maintain plant health and appearance. If the plant becomes too leggy or overgrown, trim it back to encourage bushier growth. Pruning is best done in the spring before the growing season begins. Sterilize pruning tools before use to prevent disease spread. Trimming will also help in managing seed dispersal, as the plant can be prolific if not controlled. Be gentle to avoid damaging young stems and foliage if the plant is tender."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Annual Trampweed","description":"Facelis retusa (annual trampweed) is a South American species flowering plants in the sunflower family. It is native Brazil, Bolivia, Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, Chile; naturalized in parts of Africa, Australia, and North America including the southeastern and south-central United States, and considered as a noxious weed in some of those places.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Gray-green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America"],"other_name":["Annual Trampweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Facelis retusa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17692,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Anemone coronaria requires regular watering to thrive, especially during its growing season in spring and early summer. It's important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. Water the plant thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During the dormant period in summer and fall, reduce the frequency of watering to prevent rot. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and protect the roots from temperature fluctuations. Be mindful of the local climate and rainfall to adjust the watering schedule accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Anemone coronaria thrives in a sunny location with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. This plant can tolerate partial shade, particularly in regions with hot summers, where some afternoon shade can protect it from intense heat. However, full sun exposure tends to yield the best flowering results, promoting vibrant and abundant blooms. When planting, choose a location with rich, well-draining soil. If the natural light conditions are inadequate, consider supplementing with grow lights to ensure the plant receives sufficient light for optimal growth and development. Adjust based on specific regional conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Anemone coronaria is relatively straightforward and focuses mainly on deadheading and maintaining plant health. Remove spent flowers by cutting the stem back to the base to encourage further blooming and prolong the flowering period. Additionally, trim any yellowing or damaged foliage during the growing season to improve the plant's appearance and prevent disease. In late fall or early winter, after the foliage has died back completely, cut the plant back to ground level. This allows the plant to conserve energy for the next growing season, ensuring vigorous growth and blooming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"poppy anemone","description":"Anemone coronaria, the poppy anemone, Spanish marigold, or windflower, is a species of flowering plant in the genus Anemone, native to the Mediterranean region.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red, White, Pink, Blue, Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["poppy anemone"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Tuber division"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Anemone coronaria"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17600,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hura polyandra, commonly known as the sandbox tree, does not require a lot of watering once it is established. This tree prefers well-draining soil and should be watered deeply but infrequently to prevent waterlogging. Allow the top several inches of the soil to dry out before watering again. During the dry season or in times of drought, you might need to increase the frequency slightly. Be cautious not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. Regular, consistent watering during the early years is important to help establish a strong root system."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hura polyandra thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth, this tree should ideally receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate some shade, too much shade can lead to poor growth and reduced vigor. When planting a young sandbox tree, choose a location with plenty of sunlight to ensure healthy and robust development. If you live in an area with very intense sunlight, providing slight shade during the hottest part of the day can help protect newly planted or young trees."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Hura polyandra is generally minimal but may be necessary to remove dead or damaged branches, which should be done with care due to the toxic sap it exudes. Prune during the dormant season or just before the growth period in late winter to early spring, using clean tools to make precise cuts. Gloves and protective clothing should be worn to avoid contact with the sap. Regular pruning is not needed, but occasionally thinning out branches can help improve air circulation and maintain the tree's structure, especially if growing in a landscape setting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Hura polyandra"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17503,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oenothera gaura, commonly known as beeblossom or gaura, prefers well-drained soil and moderate watering. It's quite drought-tolerant once established, making it low maintenance in terms of watering needs. Water the plant deeply but infrequently to encourage deep root growth, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's important to ensure proper drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in waterlogged conditions. During prolonged dry spells or in the summer heat, you might need to increase the frequency slightly, observing the plant's needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oenothera gaura thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to bloom profusely. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight may lead to fewer blossoms and leggy growth. Ensure the plant receives plenty of morning sunlight, ideally in an area with well-drained soil. Positioning in a spot where it can bask in direct sunlight for the majority of the day will result in vibrant and healthy blooms. Adequate sunlight is crucial for fostering a robust flowering display throughout the growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oenothera gaura is beneficial to maintain its shape, encourage bushier growth, and extend the blooming period. In early spring, trim back any dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy growth. During the growing season, deadheading spent blooms can promote continuous flowering. After the flowering season, in late autumn, you may cut the plant back to about one-third of its height to tidy up the appearance and prevent it from becoming too leggy. Regular pruning not only helps keep the plant neat but also supports its overall health and vigor."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"biennial beeblossom","description":"Gaura biennis, commonly known as biennial gaura or biennial beeblossom, is a native (North American) biennial plant that can reach anywhere from 4–6 feet in height at maturity. Its upper half is made up of flowering stems, which are covered with soft, white hairs. G. biennis is most well known for its light pink colored flowers, which turn a vibrant red/pink color in the late summer to early fall seasons (typically August to September). {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17296,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Loropetalum chinense prefers consistently moist but well-drained soil. Water the plant deeply when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. In the growing season, which is usually spring and summer, you may need to water more frequently, especially in hot weather. Take care to avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot. Reduce the watering frequency during the fall and winter months, unless the conditions are particularly dry. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and keep the roots cool during hot weather."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Loropetalum chinense thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth and vibrant leaf coloration, it benefits from at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight per day. Plants in hotter climates may appreciate some afternoon shade to prevent leaf scorch and stress. In cooler regions, providing more sun exposure can enhance blooming and growth. If planted in too much shade, blooming potential may decrease, and the foliage color may become less intense. Choosing the right sunlight exposure will help maintain its health and vibrant aesthetic."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Loropetalum chinense should be done after flowering in the late spring or early summer. Trim back any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to maintain the plant’s health and appearance. To promote a bushier growth, you can pin back long shoots. However, prune sparingly to preserve the plant's natural shape and avoid cutting back more than one-third of the shrub at any one time. Regular light pruning is best to encourage dense foliage and vibrant flowering. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chinese fringe flower","description":"Loropetalum chinense is commonly known as the Chinese fringe flower. Two forms of L. chinense exist; a white- (to pale-yellow-) flowering green-leafed variety and a pink-flowering variety with leaves varying from bronze-red when new to olive-green or burgundy when mature, depending on selection and growing conditions.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green or Burgundy"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Japan","Himalayas","Southeast Asia"],"other_name":["Chinese fringe flower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Whitefly","Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Loropetalum chinense"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17898,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tinantia pringlei prefers consistently moist soil, but it should be well-draining to prevent root rot. This plant does not like to dry out completely between waterings, so it's important to monitor the moisture level of the soil regularly, especially during hot or dry periods. Regular watering is necessary, typically once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. However, overwatering should be avoided, as it can lead to soggy soil conditions and root issues. Adjust watering frequency depending on environmental conditions such as humidity and temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tinantia pringlei thrives in bright, indirect light but can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates. Direct sunlight can scorch the leaves, so it's best to avoid placing them in areas with intense midday sun exposure. Indoors, a spot near an east or north-facing window works well, or if outdoors, a location with filtered light or partial shade is ideal. Adjust the plant's position to ensure it receives adequate light for healthy growth but avoid prolonged exposure to harsh, direct sunlight which may cause leaf burn."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tinantia pringlei is generally minimal but can be done to encourage bushier growth and to remove any dead or damaged leaves. It's best to prune during the plant's growing season, typically in spring and summer. Trim the plant by pinching off the tips of the stems or using a pair of clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears. This can help the plant maintain a tidy appearance and promote healthy, new growth. Regular cleaning of fallen leaves around the base is also advisable to prevent pest and disease issues."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Spotted Widow's Tears","description":"Tinantia pringlei, sometimes known as the Mexican wandering Jew, is a perennial alpine plant in the dayflower family native to northeastern Mexico. In particularly hot or dry climates, you may need to water more frequently, while in cooler, moist conditions, less water is required."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lupinus sericeus thrives best in full sunlight, needing at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun each day to develop robustly and produce ample blooms. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent overwatering which can lead to root rot. During winter months or dormant periods, reduce watering frequency. Proper sunlight ensures vigorous growth and healthy flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cascabela thevetia should be done to maintain shape, size, and health of the plant. Pruning is best done in early spring before the new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve airflow and sunlight penetration. You can also prune to shape the plant according to your visual preference, whether as a shrub or small tree. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and avoid spread of plant diseases. Regular pruning encourages bushier growth and more abundant flowering. Always handle with care as the plant is toxic."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Be-still tree","description":"Cascabela thevetia (syn: Thevetia peruviana) is a poisonous plant native throughout Mexico and in Central America, and cultivated widely as an ornamental. If you're dealing with plants affected by this rust, focus on maintaining the health and vigor of the host plant by ensuring proper watering practices. Avoid overhead watering, as moisture on leaves can promote fungal growth, and instead, water directly at the soil level."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"While Puccinia lagenophorae does not require sunlight per se, its presence on host plants can be affected by light conditions. Host plants, like those in the Senecio genus, generally thrive in full sunlight, which can help reduce humidity levels and deter the spread of rust fungi. Ensure the infected plants receive optimal light exposure to aid their health and resilience. Well-lit environments can lower the favorable conditions for rust fungi colonization and spread."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For plants affected by Puccinia lagenophorae, also known as the common groundsel rust, pruning is more about disease control. Remove and destroy any infected plant material to halt the spread of the rust. Regularly check plants for early signs of infection, like orange pustules on leaves, and prune these areas promptly. Ensure tools are sterilized between cuts to prevent spreading the rust to healthy parts of the plant or to other plants. This method helps in managing rust outbreaks effectively."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Groundsel crown rust","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Groundsel crown rust"],"pest_susceptibility":["Rust fungi"],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Puccinia lagenophorae"],"soil":[],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It forms symbiotic associations with plant roots, helping them absorb nutrients and water more efficiently. If cultivated intentionally, it's crucial to mimic its natural habitat by providing occasional moisture but avoiding excessive waterlogging. Ensuring the soil has excellent drainage will help maintain an appropriate environment. Typically, natural rainfall will suffice, and supplemental watering is rarely needed unless there is a prolonged dry period."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pisolithus arhizus, unlike many plants, is a fungus and does not have traditional needs for sunlight as it doesn’t perform photosynthesis. It naturally grows in a variety of lighting conditions, including full sun to shaded areas, depending on its symbiotic relationship with nearby plants. The important factor is ensuring the right environmental conditions in terms of soil and moisture to support its host plants. As it's resilient, finding the right plant companions is more crucial than directly managing its light exposure. It can assist plants in accessing nutrients across a range of sunlit environments."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As Pisolithus arhizus is a fungus rather than a traditional plant with stems and leaves, it does not require pruning in the conventional sense. There is no above-ground structure that benefits from being cut back. However, you may want to manage its growth by controlling the environment where it thrives. If growing near desired plants, ensure that it is not invading critical root space. Removal is typically managed by digging around and gently extracting the fungal body if necessary, but traditional pruning tools are not applicable here."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dyeball","description":"Pisolithus arhizus is a widespread earth-ball like fungus, which may in fact be several closely related species. Common names include dead man's foot and dyeball. It is known in Australia as the horse dung fungus, in South Africa as perdebal, and in Europe as the Bohemian truffle. This puffball's black viscous gel is used as a natural dye for clothes. Pisolithus arhizus is a major component in mycorrhizal fungus mixtures that are used in gardening as","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia","North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Dyeball"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["December"],"scientific_name":["Pisolithus arhizus"],"soil":["Acidic","Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Then, allow the soil to dry out completely before watering again, especially during the growing season in spring and summer. It is well-adapted to very bright and hot environments, typical of desert habitats. Indoor placement should be near a south-facing window where it can receive ample direct sunlight. If growing outdoors, choose a spot that receives plenty of sunshine. In inadequate lighting conditions, the cactus may etiolate, meaning it will stretch out and weaken as it seeks more light, negatively impacting its appearance and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ferocactus emoryi is minimal and mainly involves removing old or damaged parts. Dead or yellowing parts should be gently cut back using clean, sharp tools to prevent any disease. Since this cactus has sharp spines, care should be taken to protect your hands during pruning activities. Avoid cutting into the main stem of the plant, as this can introduce pathogens and harm the cactus. Pruning primarily promotes better air circulation around the plant and keeps its appearance tidy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Emory's barrel cactus","description":"Ferocactus emoryi, known commonly as Emory's barrel cactus, Coville's barrel cactus and traveler's friend, is a barrel cactus in the genus Ferocactus.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Emory's barrel cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Ferocactus emoryi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Late summer or early fall is the best time to do a more thorough cleaning, reducing size if necessary, but take care to not cut into the older wood as it might not regenerate."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"cleft phlox","description":"Phlox bifida, the cleft phlox or sand phlox, is native to the Midwestern United States, the Ozarks, and the cedar glades of Kentucky and Tennessee. Adequate sunlight is essential for healthy growth and flowering of this species."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Echinocereus santaritensis is minimal. During the growing season, which typically spans from spring to early fall, water the cactus thoroughly but allow the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. This usually translates to watering approximately every two to four weeks, depending on climate and humidity levels. In winter, reduce waterings significantly or cease altogether, as the plant enters a period of dormancy. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's essential to use well-draining soil and avoid letting the cactus sit in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ferocactus wislizeni thrives in full sunlight. Provide it with at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. This cactus prefers bright, unfiltered light, typical of its native desert habitat. If the cactus becomes top-heavy or develops offsets, you can cut these off at the base using clean, sharp tools. Avoid aggressive pruning or the use of tools that might disturb the substrate to which the lichen is attached. Water the plant thoroughly to allow the water to reach its deep root system and then let the topsoil dry out before watering again. Seasonal adjustments are necessary, reducing watering in cooler, dormant seasons and increasing during active growth periods. Be mindful of the plant's environment; potted soils may dry faster and may need more frequent watering compared to ground-grown plants."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arachis duranensis thrives best with full sun exposure, which means it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. Regularly inspect the plant and remove any dead or diseased leaves to improve air circulation and minimize the risk of fungal diseases. Pruning is also a good opportunity to check for pests and other issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wild Peanut","description":"Arachis duranensis (syn. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16404,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Festuca gigantea, commonly known as giant fescue grass, prefers a moderately moist environment. Watering should be done regularly to keep the soil consistently damp, especially during dry spells in summer. However, it is important to ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging. The plant is somewhat drought-tolerant once established, but young plants require more frequent watering. A good practice is to water deeply and allow the topsoil to dry out slightly between waterings, to encourage deep root growth and a more drought-resistant plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Festuca gigantea thrives best in sites that receive full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should get at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day to flourish. While it can tolerate some shade, too much can lead to leggy and weak growth. The plant is adaptable to various light conditions but performs best with adequate sunlight, which helps in maintaining its compact, dense form. If planted in an overly shaded area, the foliage might become sparse, and the plant may not perform optimally, impacting its vigor and growth habit."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Festuca gigantea is generally straightforward and mainly involves cleaning up dead or damaged foliage. In late winter or early spring, before new growth appears, cut back any old or tatty leaves to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage healthy new growth. You can trim back to ground level if necessary. If the plant is used in a meadow or as ornamental grass in a landscape, occasional mowing or cutting back can help control its size and prevent flowering if desired. Regular cutting will also prevent self-seeding and help maintain its shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Giant Fescue","description":"Festuca gigantea, or giant fescue, is a plant species in the Poaceae (grass family). Because this and other members of Festuca subgenus Schedonorus have more in common morphologically with members of the genus Lolium than with Festuca and often produce fertile hybrids with other Lolium species, Festuca gigantea has been recently published as Lolium giganteum (L.) Darbysh. (1993) and then as Schedonorus giganteus (L.) Holub (1998). Sources vary as to which placement is more acceptable.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Giant Fescue"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Festuca gigantea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When grown indoors, placing the plant near a north or east-facing window would ensure it receives adequate indirect light. This can be done at any time of the year, though it is useful to tidy up the plant in early spring before new growth begins. Cutting back the plant by a third can stimulate denser foliage. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and minimize any potential damage or disease. Regular removal of old foliage also helps to prevent the spread of pests and diseases."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"heath wood-rush","description":"Luzula multiflora, the common woodrush or heath wood-rush, is a species of flowering plant in the rush family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["heath wood-rush"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Luzula multiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

While they can tolerate some shade, sufficient light helps maintain their vibrant blooms and compact growth habit."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Myosotis ramosissima is generally minimal. To encourage a tidy appearance and prolonged blooming, remove spent flowers regularly, a practice known as deadheading. This will help prevent the plant from exerting energy into seed production and instead focus on growth and forming new blooms. At the end of the growing season, you can cut back the plant to tidy its appearance or leave some growth to provide seeds for the next season's self-sowing. Excessive cutting can be avoided since it’s a small annual plant and doesn't require heavy pruning."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Early Forget-me-not","description":"Myosotis ramosissima or early forget-me-not is a flowering plant species in the family Boraginaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Early Forget-me-not"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Myosotis ramosissima"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's best done during its dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp tools to make smooth cuts, which helps the plant heal better and reduces the chance of infection. Regular pruning can also help control the plant's size and encourage a bushier appearance by cutting back any leggy growth. Additionally, removing spent flowers can improve the plant's overall appearance and encourage more vigorous blooming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Darwin's cotton","description":"Gossypium darwinii, or Darwin's cotton, is a species of cotton plant which is found only on the Galapagos Islands. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17802,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Xiphidium caeruleum, commonly known as the \"Blue-flowered Ginger,\" prefers consistently moist soil. Water the plant regularly to maintain an even level of moisture, but ensure the pot or soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging. Typically, watering once or twice a week should suffice, but this could vary depending on the plant's environment and season. It's crucial to let the top inch of soil dry out slightly between waterings to avoid root rot. During the growing season, increase watering, while in the dormant phase, water sparingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Xiphidium caeruleum thrives in medium to bright indirect sunlight. It can tolerate direct morning sunlight, but should be sheltered from harsh midday and afternoon sun, which can scorch the leaves. If growing indoors, placing it near a bright east or west-facing window will optimize light conditions. In outdoor settings, under filtered light or partial shade conditions, such as under larger trees, works well. Sufficient light ensures it blooms well, but be cautious of too much direct sun, which can damage the plant. Adjust the placement based on seasonal light variations."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Xiphidium caeruleum involves removing dead or wilted flowers and leaves to encourage new growth and maintain its aesthetic appeal. This can be done throughout the growing season as needed. Regular deadheading (removal of spent flowers) will also stimulate further blooming. For any larger pruning tasks, focus on shaping the plant by cutting back to a leaf node or just above where the leaf meets the stem. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent disease spread. Pruning is typically minimal, as the plant tends to maintain a neat appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"palmita","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["palmita"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Xiphidium caeruleum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17604,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Metopium brownei, commonly known as the Black Poisonwood, prefers a well-draining soil and should be watered moderately. It is drought-tolerant once established, so avoid overwatering. Allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions during the growing season, and reduce watering significantly in the fall and winter. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure that the pot or planting area allows excess water to escape. Always water deeply to encourage a robust root system, but do not allow the plant to sit in standing water for extended periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Metopium brownei thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. It grows best when exposed to at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. In regions with intense sunlight, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf burn, especially when the plant is young. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure encourages denser foliage and more vigorous growth. When planting in a new location, gradually acclimate the plant to increased sunlight to minimize stress. This adaptability makes it suitable for various landscaping environments."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Metopium brownei should be done with care, as its sap can cause skin irritation. Wear protective gloves and long sleeves when pruning. The best time to prune is during the dormant months of late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration. Pruning can also help shape the tree and control its size, especially if grown in a landscape setting. After pruning, clean tools thoroughly to remove any sap and prevent skin contact."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Black Poisonwood","description":"Metopium brownei (also known as chechem, chechen, or black poisonwood) is a species of plant in the Anacardiaceae family. It is found in the Dominican Republic, Cuba, Jamaica, northern Guatemala, Belize, Bonaire, Curacao, Aruba(rare) and from the Yucatán to Veracruz in Mexico. The wood of this tree is a valuable source of lumber in Central America and the West Indies. Like its cousin Florida Poisonwood (Metopium toxiferum), it produces urushiol in its bark, which can cause...","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish-white","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Black Poisonwood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Metopium brownei"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17901,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trichocentrum cebolleta, commonly known as \"the Onion Plant,\" prefers moderate watering. This orchid-like plant should be allowed to dry out slightly between waterings. In the growing season, which typically spans spring through autumn, water it thoroughly when the top inch of the potting medium feels dry to the touch. Reduce watering during the winter dormant period, as the plant requires less moisture. Always ensure that the plant is in well-draining soil to prevent root rot, and avoid letting the plant sit in water for extended periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trichocentrum cebolleta thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It is best to place this plant in a location where it can receive ample morning light without direct exposure to hot afternoon sun, which may scorch its leaves. An east-facing window is typically ideal. If placed in a window with direct sunlight, such as south or west-facing, ensure that it is diffused with a sheer curtain. During the winter, when sunlight is less intense, it can tolerate a bit more direct light. Monitor the plant for any signs of sunburn and adjust its position accordingly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Trichocentrum cebolleta is relatively straightforward. Regularly remove spent blooms and any yellowing or dead leaves to encourage healthy growth and prevent disease. You can use sterilized pruning shears or scissors to trim these parts back to the base of the plant. Be cautious not to cut healthy green stems or leaves, as this can disrupt growth. Besides aesthetic maintenance, this plant does not require significant pruning efforts. Pruning after the blooming season helps redirect energy into new growth and flower production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Mealybugs","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Trichocentrum cebolleta"],"soil":["Well-drained","Bark medium"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17695,"attracts":["Birds","Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Banksia integrifolia requires moderate watering. It is important to allow the soil to dry out partially between watering sessions. During the initial establishment phase, provide additional water, especially during dry spells. Established plants can tolerate some drought, but thrive best with occasional deep watering. Over-watering should be avoided as waterlogged conditions can cause root rot. Adjust your watering frequency to ensure the soil is consistently moist but not wet, particularly in hotter months. Mulching around the base can help retain moisture and maintain even soil temperatures."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Banksia integrifolia thrives best in full sun, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate partial shade, its growth and flowering are significantly enhanced with full sun exposure. In shaded conditions, the plant may grow leggy and produce fewer blooms. Additionally, adequate sunlight ensures that the plant maintains its health and vitality. Position the banksia in a spot that gets unobstructed sunlight for most of the day to ensure prolific blooming and robust growth. Adjust its placement if nearby structures or trees cast too much shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Banksia integrifolia should be conducted primarily in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Prune to maintain a desirable shape, remove any dead or damaged branches, and to open up the plant to promote air circulation. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and avoid bruising the stems. Pruning helps the shrub develop a stronger framework and encourages bushier growth. When pruning, be cautious not to cut into the older, hard wood, as this may hinder regrowth and flowering. Regular light pruning is preferable to heavy trimming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Coastal Banksia","description":"Banksia integrifolia, commonly known as coast banksia, is a species of tree that grows along the east coast of Australia. One of the most widely distributed Banksia species, it occurs between Victoria and Central Queensland in a broad range of habitats, from coastal dunes to mountains. It is highly variable in form, but is most often encountered as a tree up to 25 metres (82 ft) in height. Its leaves have dark green upper surfaces and white...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Coastal Banksia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Banksia integrifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It's important to maintain consistently moist soil, particularly during the warmer months, but avoid waterlogging the plant as this can lead to root rot. During the growing season, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. In the cooler months, reduce the frequency slightly, ensuring the soil does not dry out completely. For optimal growth, provide the plant with at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. In areas with intense afternoon sun, particularly during the summer, some light shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors, placing Ixeris chinensis near a south or east-facing window should provide sufficient light. Adjust its location as necessary to ensure it receives enough light while also being protected from harsh, direct midday sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ixeris chinensis is essential to encourage bushier growth and to remove dead or damaged leaves and stems. Regularly inspect the plant and prune back any overgrown stems after the flowering period to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Deadheading flowers can also encourage further blooming. It's best to use clean and sharp pruning shears to prevent disease transmission. Overall, pruning can be performed as needed throughout the growing season, but heavier pruning should be reserved for late winter or early spring."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Yellow bristle-hair ixeris","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia"],"other_name":["Yellow bristle-hair ixeris"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Ixeris chinensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19105,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Myriopteris covillei, commonly known as Coville's lipfern, prefers to grow in well-drained soil and has moderate water needs. This plant is naturally adapted to rocky, arid environments, so it tolerates dry conditions better than overly wet ones. Water the plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out almost completely between waterings. When grown indoors or in gardens, it's best to emulate its natural habitat by watering once every two weeks or so, depending on humidity and temperature levels. Be attentive to the signs of overwatering, like yellowing leaves, as the plant does not thrive in overly moist conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Myriopteris covillei thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also tolerate partial shade. In its natural habitat, it often grows in rocky, exposed areas where it receives a good amount of light without direct, harsh rays for prolonged periods. If you are cultivating it indoors, place the fern near a window where it can receive filtered or indirect sunlight to mimic its natural growing conditions. Avoid prolonged exposure to direct afternoon sun, which might scorch its delicate fronds. For outdoor growth, pick a location with partial shade or dappled light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Myriopteris covillei is mostly about maintaining its appearance and removing any dead or damaged fronds. This plant doesn't require heavy pruning, but occasional tidying will help keep it looking its best. Remove dead or yellowing fronds with sharp, clean scissors or a pruning shear to encourage new growth and to prevent any potential pest infestations. It's also useful to check the plant regularly and prune during its active growing season in spring and summer for optimal health and appearance management."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Coville's lip fern","description":"Cheilanthes covillei, reclassified as Myriopteris covillei, is a species of lip fern known by the common name Coville's lip fern.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Coville's lip fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Myriopteris covillei"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17402,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fouquieria columnaris, commonly known as the Boojum tree, is adapted to arid conditions and requires very little water. During its growing season in spring and early summer, water it lightly to maintain slight soil moisture, but ensure the soil dries out thoroughly between waterings to prevent root rot. In the dormant winter months, reduce watering significantly, allowing the plant to remain mostly dry. Overwatering can be detrimental, so mimic its natural desert habitat by prioritizing drainage and infrequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Boojum tree thrives in full sun conditions, mimicking the bright, intense sunlight of its native desert habitat. It should receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. Plant it in a location where it won’t be overshadowed by larger plants or structures, as insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and poor plant health. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent sunburned foliage, especially for younger plants. Always ensure good airflow around the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Fouquieria columnaris is minimal, as it naturally develops a unique form over time. Prune only to remove dead or damaged branches, ideally in late winter or early spring, before new growth starts. Use clean, sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts, which help prevent disease. Avoid heavy pruning, as it can disrupt the plant’s natural structure. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, especially during its active growing season in spring and summer, ensuring water drains well to prevent waterlogging. During the cooler months of fall and winter, reduce the frequency of watering, allowing natural rainfall to assist if the plant is outdoors. Always adjust watering based on humidity and temperature to maintain optimal soil moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Melicytus lanceolatus prefers a location with full sunlight to partial shade. Monitoring the plant's light exposure and adjusting its location if necessary can ensure it receives the appropriate amount of sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Melicytus lanceolatus is not typically required unless you're managing its shape or size. Regular light pruning can keep the plant tidy and maintain its ornamental appearance, particularly in cultivated landscapes."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Māhoe Wao","description":"Melicytus lanceolatus, commonly called Narrow-leaved māhoe or māhoe-wao, is a small tree of the family Violaceae endemic to New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia","New Zealand"],"other_name":["Māhoe Wao"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Melicytus lanceolatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Evening"}}

If natural light is insufficient, consider using artificial grow lights to supplement lighting needs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lasianthus attenuatus is generally minimal and primarily revolves around maintaining its shape and removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. To encourage a bushier growth habit, occasionally prune the tips of the branches. While it enjoys moisture, it’s important to avoid waterlogged conditions that could lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During the winter months, reduce the frequency of watering while maintaining sufficient humidity levels around the plant by misting or placing a tray of water nearby to ensure it doesn’t dry out too much."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This tropical plant thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can tolerate some full sun, especially in cooler climates. However, too much direct sunlight, particularly in hot afternoons, can scorch the leaves. It’s ideally placed in a spot where it receives morning sun and afternoon shade. Indoors, it does well in a room with plenty of natural light, perhaps near an east or north-facing window. During winter, when light levels can be lower, you may want to move it to a sunnier spot to ensure it gets enough light to thrive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Justicia carnea is recommended to maintain a bushy, compact shape and encourage new growth. Prune in early spring before new growth begins, by cutting back the stems to about half their size. This encourages the development of more branches, resulting in a fuller plant. Remove any dead or damaged foliage throughout the year to keep the plant healthy. Light trimming can also be done after the blooming period to remove spent flowers and tidying up the shape, which might stimulate another round of blooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"King's-crown","description":"Justicia carnea, with common names including Brazilian plume flower, Brazilian-plume, flamingo flower, and jacobinia — is a flowering plant in the family Acanthaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Brazil","South America"],"other_name":["King's-crown"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider Mites","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Justicia carnea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Be cautious during the hot summer months, as the soil can dry out more quickly. However, make sure to reduce watering during the winter months when the plant is dormant. At the end of the growing season, you can trim back the plant lightly to prepare it for winter dormancy, which may help promote more vigorous growth in spring."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Long-spurred Violet","description":"Viola calcarata is a species of genus Viola that grows on mountains of south-eastern Europe. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade may protect the plant from scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Zephyranthes carinata is minimal and mostly involves deadheading. Remove spent flowers by cutting the flower stalks down to the base to encourage more blooms and prevent seed formation. This also helps the plant to focus its energy on growth and bulb development. If the foliage becomes unsightly or damaged, you can tidy the plant by trimming off any yellow or brown leaves. However, do not remove healthy green leaves, as they are crucial for photosynthesis and replenishing the bulb's energy stores."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Rose Pink Zephyr Lily","description":"Zephyranthes carinata, commonly known as the rosepink zephyr lily or pink rain lily, is a perennial flowering plant native to Mexico, Colombia and Central America. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17696,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Echinocereus dasyacanthus, commonly known as the Texas Rainbow Cactus, requires careful watering to prevent root rot. Water the cactus thoroughly during its active growing season in spring and summer, allowing the soil to dry completely between waterings. Ensure the pot has drainage holes to avoid waterlogging. During fall and winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters dormancy. Depending on humidity levels, you might only need to water it once every few weeks during this period. Remember that less is more when it comes to watering cacti."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Echinocereus dasyacanthus thrives in bright, direct sunlight and should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight a day. Position the cactus in a south or west-facing window to ensure it gets ample light. If natural light is insufficient, especially during the winter months, consider supplementing with a grow light. Without enough light, the cactus may become elongated or etiolated. Gradually adapt the plant to any changes in light conditions to prevent sunburn, especially if moving it outdoors during the warmer months."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Echinocereus dasyacanthus is generally minimal but can be beneficial for removing dead or damaged stems which can help maintain the plant's health. If your cactus grows some offsets you don't want, these can also be pruned and repotted if desired. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to make cuts, and try to avoid cutting into healthy green areas. Allow the cut areas to callus over before watering again, as this helps prevent infections or disease. Always wear protective gloves to avoid injury from the cactus spines."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Texas rainbow cactus","description":"Echinocereus dasyacanthus is a member of the cactus family, Cactaceae. It is one of about 2000 total species belonging to this family. The cactus is commonly known as Texas rainbow cactus because of the subtle rings or bands of contrasting colors along the stem of the plant. Not all Texas rainbow cacti have the \"rainbow\" coloration on their stems. Another common name is spiny hedgehog cactus.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Texas rainbow cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Echinocereus dasyacanthus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems at the base. Throughout the growing season, occasional light pruning can help maintain its desired shape and support blooming. Minimal pruning is typically needed for aesthetic purposes or to keep pathways clear. Be cautious of the thorns when pruning and take care to create an open, well-ventilated canopy to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sweet Thorn","description":"Vachellia karroo, commonly known as the Sweet thorn, is a species of acacia, native to southern Africa from southern Angola east to Mozambique, and south to South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Southern Africa"],"other_name":["Sweet Thorn"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Vachellia karroo"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Overwatering can rot the bulbs, so allow the top couple of inches of soil to dry out before watering again. Reduce watering in the dormancy period after the plant has bloomed and the leaves begin to yellow. This species is drought-tolerant once established, but regular watering during active growth will support vibrant blooms and healthy foliage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tulipa agenensis thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. If planting in a hotter climate, some afternoon shade can help prevent excessive heat stress and prolong blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tulipa agenensis is a straightforward process. After blooming, the flowers can be deadheaded by removing spent blooms to direct the plant's energy back to the bulb rather than seed production. However, keep the foliage intact until it withers, as the leaves photosynthesize and provide energy to the bulb for the next growing season. Once the leaves have yellowed and died back naturally, they can be pruned away. This allows the plant to complete its growth cycle and ensures robust growth in the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Eyed Tulip","description":"Tulipa agenensis is a Middle Eastern species of flowering plants in the family Liliaceae. Ensure the soil remains consistently damp, particularly during the spring and summer months when the plant is actively growing. During the dormant period in winter, reduce watering to prevent soggy soil conditions. Using mulch can help maintain soil moisture, but the mulch should not be placed directly against the stem to avoid rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ranunculus lyallii thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of sunlight per day. In climates with intense afternoon sun, providing some light afternoon shade can help to protect the plant from excessive heat and sun scorch. While providing enough light is crucial for robust flowering and growth, care should be taken to ensure the plant does not dry out in very sunny spots. A location with morning sun and afternoon shade often provides the optimal balance for health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ranunculus lyallii involves removing dead or damaged leaves and spent flowers to encourage healthy growth and prevent disease. This plant does not require extensive pruning but benefits from regular maintenance to remove any foliage that may have been damaged by pests or environmental factors. In late autumn, after the plant has finished flowering, it is advisable to cut back any dead flower stalks. However, avoid cutting back healthy foliage excessively as the leaves continue to store nutrients that can be used for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mount Cook lily","description":"Ranunculus lyallii (Mountain buttercup, Mount Cook buttercup, or, although not a lily, Mount Cook lily), is a species of Ranunculus (buttercup), endemic to New Zealand, where it occurs in the South Island and on Stewart Island at altitudes of 700–1,500 m.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Mount Cook lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Ranunculus lyallii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18707,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hoheria sexstylosa, commonly known as Lacebark Tree, prefers a moderate watering regime. Ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which the roots are particularly sensitive to. During the growing season in spring and summer, water the plant thoroughly once a week. In hotter, drier periods, increase watering frequency to twice a week. In contrast, reduce watering during the fall and winter months when the plant's growth slows. Always check the top layer of soil before watering; it should be dry to the touch to avoid overwatering. Mulching can help retain moisture during dry spells."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hoheria sexstylosa thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It prefers conditions where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day, which encourages robust flowering and healthy growth. However, in regions with intense summer heat, a location with some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. While the plant can tolerate partial shade, too much shade may lead to reduced flowering and leggier growth. Ensure it is planted in a spot where it can receive ample light but is shielded from the harsh midday sun if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hoheria sexstylosa is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Prune the plant in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Start by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Next, thin out any crowded areas to increase air circulation, which helps prevent diseases. Cut back overly long branches to maintain the desired shape and size of the tree. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant. Light annual pruning will suffice to keep the Lacebark Tree looking its best and promote a healthy structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"long-leaved lacebark","description":"Hoheria sexstylosa (long-leaved lacebark or ribbonwood) is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae, endemic to New Zealand. It is an evergreen tree or shrub growing to 8 m (26 ft) tall by 6 m (20 ft) broad with glossy green leaves, and white flowers in summer and autumn. This tree tends to have a weeping graceful habit and is sometimes sold by nurseries with the name graceful lacebark. The Latin term sexstylosa means \"six styles\".","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["long-leaved lacebark"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Hoheria sexstylosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17997,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Burchellia bubalina prefers moderate watering to maintain its health and vibrancy. During the growing season, which is typically spring through summer, you should water the plant regularly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. This ensures the plant receives adequate moisture without becoming waterlogged. In the dormant season, reduce the frequency of watering, only providing enough to prevent the soil from becoming completely dry. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has good drainage and the soil is well-aerated."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Burchellia bubalina thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, but it can also tolerate some direct sun, particularly in the morning or late afternoon. If placed indoors, a location near a window that receives plenty of natural light is ideal. While it can withstand short periods of lower light, prolonged exposure to inadequate light conditions can result in reduced flowering and less vibrant foliage. Avoid intense, direct midday sun, which can scorch the leaves. In regions with hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Burchellia bubalina is beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging new growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote healthy growth. Additionally, prune to thin out crowded areas, allowing more light and air to reach the inner parts of the plant. Always use clean and sharp pruning tools to prevent disease spread. Be cautious not to remove more than one-third of the plant’s volume at a time to reduce stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wild Pomegranate","description":"Burchellia is a monotypic genus of flowering plants in the Rubiaceae family. The genus contains only one species, viz. Burchellia bubalina, which is endemic to southern Africa: the Cape Provinces, KwaZulu-Natal and the Northern Provinces in South Africa, and Swaziland. It is commonly known as \"wild pomegranate\" (English) or \"wildegranaat\" (Afrikaans).","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Wild Pomegranate"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Burchellia bubalina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If grown indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window. If the plant appears to be stretching or the fronds are losing color, it may be receiving too little light, in which case it can be moved to a brighter spot."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Myriopteris lindheimeri should be done minimally, primarily to remove any dead or damaged fronds, which can be carefully cut back to the base of the plant. This encourages healthy new growth and maintains the plant's appearance. It is best to prune during the plant's dormant period in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Make sure to use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant or spreading disease. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17404,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Yucca gigantea, also known as the Spineless Yucca, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires infrequent watering. Allow the top couple of inches of soil to dry out thoroughly between waterings. Water deeply but less frequently, which is generally every two to three weeks, depending on light and temperature conditions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has proper drainage and never let the plant sit in water. In winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant enters a period of dormancy and requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Yucca gigantea thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also handle some direct sun exposure. Ideally, place the plant in a spot that gets plenty of natural light, such as near southeast or south-facing windows. While it can adapt to moderate light conditions, it will not grow as vigorously in low light. If growing outside, ensure it has enough space and light, while being sheltered from harsh midday sunlight in hot climates, as this can cause leaf burn. Rotate the plant occasionally to encourage even growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Yucca gigantea is necessary to remove dead or damaged leaves and to maintain an attractive shape. Prune in the spring just before the plant's growth spurt. Remove any yellow, brown, or damaged leaves by cutting them off at the base. For taller plants, you can trim the tops of the stems to control height, which also encourages branching and a fuller appearance. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent infection and make clean cuts. Wearing gloves is advisable due to the plant's sharp leaf tips and possible sap irritation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Spineless Yucca","description":"Yucca gigantea (syn. Yucca elephantipes, Yucca guatemalensis), is a Yucca species that is native to Belize, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and the eastern part of Mexico (Quintana Roo, Yucatán, Campeche, Tabasco, Chiapas, Veracruz, eastern Puebla and southern Tamaulipas). It is also reportedly naturalized in Puerto Rico, the Leeward Islands and Ecuador.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Spineless Yucca"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Scale insects","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Yucca gigantea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17998,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cornus racemosa, commonly known as gray dogwood, prefers moist, well-drained soils but can tolerate a variety of conditions once established. Water young plants regularly to help them establish a deep root system. For mature specimens, provide water during prolonged dry spells, especially during hot summer months. The soil should remain moist, but not waterlogged, as overly wet conditions can lead to root rot. In areas with frequent rainfall, additional irrigation may be unnecessary. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain an even temperature around the roots. Overall, gray dogwood is quite adaptable to diverse moisture conditions once it's established."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cornus racemosa thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth and flowering, provide at least four to six hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch and mitigate the stress of excessive heat. However, in cooler regions, more sun exposure could enhance blooming and foliage color. Positioning the plant in a location that provides morning sun and afternoon shade can strike a good balance. Its adaptable nature also means it can grow under a variety of light conditions, though more sun does typically yield the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cornus racemosa should be conducted in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This timing helps to maintain the plant's shape and encourages healthy, vigorous growth. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to keep the shrub healthy. Thinning out some of the older stems at the base will increase air circulation and allow more light into the center of the plant. For aesthetic shaping, trim branches as needed to maintain the desired form. Regular pruning helps foster better flowering and fruiting while preventing it from becoming overly dense and unkempt."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"gray dogwood","description":"Cornus racemosa, the northern swamp dogwood, gray dogwood or panicle dogwood, is a shrubby plant native to southeastern Canada and the northeastern United States. If grown indoors, it can be positioned near a north or east-facing window where it gets minimal direct sunshine, ensuring optimal growth without the risk of leaf burn. Adjust its position as needed if fronds show signs of burn or lack of vibrant green color."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Myriopteris myriophylla is not typically necessary for its health but can be beneficial for aesthetic reasons and to encourage growth. Remove any dead or damaged fronds by cutting them at the base of the stem. This should be done carefully to avoid injuring the healthy fronds. Remove any yellowing or dead leaves to keep the plant healthy and to promote new growth. Regular pruning can also prevent the plant from becoming too invasive if it's part of a pond or aquarium setup. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make tidy cuts just above a leaf node, which will encourage the plant to send out new growth from the cut area."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Snails","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Hydrocotyle elongata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
