{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19009,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tricyrtis formosana, commonly known as the toad lily, prefers consistently moist soil. It's vital to maintain regular watering schedules, especially during dry spells, to prevent the soil from drying out completely. It thrives in well-drained but rich, humus-filled soil that can hold moisture without becoming waterlogged. Ideally, the plant should be watered when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. During the growing season, it may require more frequent watering, while in dormant periods, the frequency can be reduced. Always avoid letting the roots sit in standing water, as this can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tricyrtis formosana thrives best in partial to full shade, making it ideal for a woodland garden setting. It tolerates filtered sunlight or dappled shade conditions well, where it can receive morning sun and afternoon shade. Too much direct sunlight, especially harsh afternoon rays, can result in leaf scorch and hinder growth. However, in cooler climates, it can handle more sun exposure. The key is to ensure that the plant receives protection from the intense midday sun, which aligns with its natural habitat under the canopy of trees in mountainous regions. "},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tricyrtis formosana involves removing dead or damaged stems and foliage to encourage healthy growth. This is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Deadheading spent blooms can also help promote additional flowering, although it's not necessary for the plant's health. Cut back the stems to ground level after the foliage has died down in autumn, which helps in tidying up the garden and preventing diseases. Regular cleaning and tidying help maintain the plant’s appearance and allow it to focus energy on producing new growth and flowers. "}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"toad lily","description":"Tricyrtis formosana is an East Asian species of herbaceous plant in the lily family. It is native to Taiwan and to Nansei-shoto (also known as the Ryukyu Islands, part of Japan).","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Taiwan"],"other_name":["toad lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Snails","Slugs"],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Tricyrtis formosana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19208,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pleurotus citrinopileatus, commonly known as the golden oyster mushroom, prefers consistently moist conditions to thrive. Watering should be done in a way that keeps the growing substrate (like straw or sawdust) damp but not waterlogged. Spraying the substrate with water regularly or using a humidity tent can assist in maintaining the required moisture levels. It is crucial to avoid letting the substrate dry out, as this could impede mushroom growth. Monitoring the humidity around the plant is key, aiming for a level around 80-90%, which can typically be sustained with periodic misting."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pleurotus citrinopileatus mushrooms thrive in indirect, low to moderate light conditions, as direct sunlight can dry out the growing substrate and damage the delicate tissue of the mushrooms. They naturally grow in shaded areas, such as under forest canopies, so replicating similar conditions indoors is beneficial. Provide a light source that mimics dappled sunlight or use ambient indoor lighting if growing them inside. Ensure they are kept out of direct harsh lights to maintain the necessary humidity and prevent drying, fostering a suitable environment for their development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically relevant for Pleurotus citrinopileatus since it is not a traditional plant but a fungus. Instead of pruning, focus on harvesting mushrooms at the right time. The ideal time to harvest is when the caps are fully opened, but before they start to curl up. Use a clean, sharp knife or twist them gently to remove. Regularly remove any mature mushrooms to encourage new growth and prevent them from rotting, which could invite pests or diseases if left unattended."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Golden Oyster Mushroom","description":"Pleurotus citrinopileatus, the golden oyster mushroom (tamogitake in Japanese), is an edible gilled fungus. Native to eastern Russia, northern China, and Japan, the golden oyster mushroom is very closely related to P. cornucopiae of Europe, with some authors considering them to be at the rank of subspecies. In far eastern Russia, P. citrinopileatus, there called iI'mak, is one of the most popular wild edible mushrooms.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Northern Asia","Eastern Europe"],"other_name":["Golden Oyster Mushroom"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Insect infestation"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Pleurotus citrinopileatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19505,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Laurophyllus capensis requires a balanced watering approach. Ensure the soil remains moist but not waterlogged, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During the growing season in spring and summer, water more frequently, approximately once a week or when you notice the soil drying out. Reduce watering during autumn and winter when the plant's growth slows, and the soil retains moisture longer. Consider environmental factors such as indoor humidity and temperature when determining the frequency, and always check the soil moisture level by inserting your finger into the substrate before watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Laurophyllus capensis thrives best in conditions of bright, indirect sunlight. Place the plant in a spot where it can receive filtered sunlight or partial shade for the majority of the day. Direct exposure to intense sun rays, especially during peak midday hours, may scorch its leaves, while too little light may affect its growth and development. If indoors, a location near an east or west-facing window, shielded by a sheer curtain, can provide ideal light conditions. Adjust the plant's position as needed if you notice signs of too much or too little sunlight, such as yellowing leaves or leggy growth, respectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Laurophyllus capensis should focus on maintaining shape, removing dead or damaged leaves, and promoting healthy growth. The best time to prune is during its dormant season in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make precise cuts just above a leaf node or stem junction. Avoid heavy pruning; instead, remove no more than one-third of the plant at a time to prevent stress. Regular pruning will encourage bushier growth and improve airflow between branches, reducing the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Iron Martin","description":"Laurophyllus is a monotypic genus of dioecious shrubs in the subfamily Anacardioideae of the cashew and sumac family Anacardiaceae. It contains the single species Laurophyllus capensis, which is endemic to the Eastern Cape province of South Africa. The species is found on wooded hillsides and by streams.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Iron Martin"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Laurophyllus capensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18214,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Euphorbia canariensis, often referred to as Canary Island Spurge, requires careful watering to prevent issues such as root rot. This plant is drought-tolerant and prefers to dry out completely between watering. During the growing season, from spring to early autumn, water the plant thoroughly but infrequently, ensuring the topsoil is dry before each watering. In contrast, reduce watering significantly in the winter months when the plant's growth slows. Always use a pot with good drainage or plant in well-draining, cactus-specific soil to prevent water from pooling around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Euphorbia canariensis thrives in abundant, bright sunlight, which is essential for its healthy growth. Ideally, this plant should be placed in a location that receives full sun for at least six hours per day. It can tolerate some light shade, especially in hotter climates, but insufficient sunlight could lead to weak, leggy growth. If growing indoors, position it near south or west-facing windows to maximize sunlight exposure. For optimal health, rotate the plant periodically to ensure even exposure to natural light, promoting balanced growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Euphorbia canariensis is generally minimal, as it has a distinctive natural growth pattern that doesn’t require shaping. However, you may prune the plant to remove dead or damaged branches and to prevent overcrowding, which can enhance light penetration for remaining stems. Pruning is best done in late winter or early spring before the growth season starts. When trimming, wear gloves and protective clothing due to the plant’s milky, irritating sap. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make cuts, and allow the cuts to callous over naturally to prevent disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Canary Island Spurge","description":"Euphorbia canariensis, commonly known as the Canary Island spurge, Hercules club or in Spanish cardón,:206 is a succulent member of the genus Euphorbia and family Euphorbiaceae endemic to the Canary Islands. It is the plant symbol of the island of Gran Canaria.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Canary Islands"],"other_name":["Canary Island Spurge"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Euphorbia canariensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water the plant regularly to keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged, as excessive water can lead to rot. It is crucial to ensure the planting medium drains well to prevent any standing water. During drier periods, increase watering frequency to compensate for the lack of humidity and natural precipitation. However, in cooler seasons or less active growth phases, reduce watering slightly to avoid over-saturation. Regular misting can also help maintain the necessary high humidity levels for this moss species."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dawsonia superba thrives in low to medium light conditions, replicating the dappled light of its native rainforest habitats. It prefers indirect sunlight when grown indoors, as direct sunlight can cause the delicate tissues of the moss to dry out and become damaged. If grown outside, find a spot that receives partial to full shade. Avoid exposing it to intense, direct midday sun, as this can lead to dehydration and stress. Ensuring the right amount of indirect light will help maintain its lush green appearance and support healthy growth. Adjust its location accordingly to provide optimal lighting conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not commonly needed for Dawsonia superba as it is a moss and does not grow to a size where pruning would be necessary for shape or vigor. However, you may gently remove any brown or dead parts that appear to keep it looking its best and to promote healthy growth. This can usually be done by pinching off the affected areas with your fingers or trimming carefully with scissors. Always ensure any pruning tools are clean to prevent the introduction of diseases. Pruning should be done as needed rather than on a fixed schedule."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"giant moss","description":"Dawsonia superba is a large moss, growing typically to 60 cm in height. It is the tallest self supporting moss in the world, but the vine Spiridens reinwardtii climbs to ten feet (3 meters). In areas with intense heat, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from excessive stress. Deadheading can be done regularly throughout the blooming season. Once flowering is complete, prune back any dead or damaged stems to maintain health and vigor. As it is a perennial, cutting back the plant to a basal rosette in late fall can help prepare it for winter dormancy. This approach ensures the plant uses its resources effectively and prevents disease and pest infestations."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Alpine Sunflower","description":"Hymenoxys grandiflora is a North American species of flowering plant in the daisy family known by the common names graylocks four-nerve daisy or graylocks rubberweed. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19011,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erythranthe moschata, commonly known as musk flower, prefers consistently moist soil conditions. It's vital to water this plant regularly, ensuring the soil is always damp but not waterlogged, which could lead to root rot. During hotter months or when the plant is exposed to prolonged sunlight, increase the watering frequency. However, in cooler or more humid conditions, you may reduce watering slightly while ensuring the soil never completely dries out. Using rainwater or distilled water can be beneficial as it avoids the build-up of minerals from tap water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erythranthe moschata thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, the plant should receive around 4 to 6 hours of sunlight daily. In hotter climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching and keep the plant from wilting. In contrast, in cooler regions, more direct sunlight helps the plant stay vibrant. If grown indoors or in a shady spot, supplementing with grow lights may be necessary to ensure healthy growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erythranthe moschata helps encourage bushier growth and more blooms. Regularly remove spent or dead flowers to prevent the plant from going to seed too soon and to prolong the blooming period. Additionally, trimming back any straggly or leggy growth can help maintain its shape and promote healthier development. Prune in early spring before new growth emerges, removing any dead or damaged stems at the base. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid infection."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"musk monkeyflower","description":"Erythranthe moschata is a species of monkeyflower known by the common names muskflower, musk monkeyflower, and formerly as the common musk, eyebright and musk plant. Ensure that the pot has good drainage to prevent root rot, and use a well-draining soil mix to help maintain the right moisture balance for the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Raukaua simplex thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, making it ideal for positioning near a window with filtered light or in a greenhouse. However, it's not tolerant of direct sunlight, which can scorch its leaves. If grown indoors, placing it near an east or north-facing window is optimal. For outdoor growth, ensure it is planted in dappled shade where it is protected from harsh midday rays. This balance ensures the plant receives adequate light for healthy growth without the risk of sun damage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Raukaua simplex can help maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. It's best to prune in spring or early summer when the plant is actively growing. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches using clean, sharp pruning shears. You can also thin out crowded areas to improve air circulation and light penetration. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the plant. Always make clean cuts just above a node or a healthy bud to encourage new growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Haumakaroa","description":"Raukaua simplex (G.Forst.) {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17700,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gentianella campestris, also known as field gentian, requires well-drained soil and moderate watering. It is crucial to ensure that the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Reduce watering frequency in the dormancy period, typically during the winter months. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is advisable to allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings. In particularly dry environments, misting can also help maintain adequate humidity levels for the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gentianella campestris thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, it should receive at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In regions with extremely hot or intense midday sun, providing some light shade during the hottest part of the day can prevent leaf scorch and promote optimal growth. However, too much shade can reduce flowering and growth vigor. For potted plants, placing them on a bright windowsill or in a location with indirect sunlight can also be beneficial. Adjust lighting conditions gradually to avoid stressing the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Gentianella campestris is minimal yet beneficial for encouraging healthy growth and enhancing its natural appearance. It is advisable to remove dead or damaged foliage and spent flowers regularly to prevent disease and stimulate more blooms. Pruning should be done in early spring before new growth starts, using clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts. This plant does not require extensive shaping but a light trim can maintain its compact form and encourage bushiness. Avoid cutting back too severely as this can shock the plant and impede its growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"field gentian","description":"Gentianella campestris, common name field gentian, is a herbaceous biennial flowering plant in the Gentianaceae (gentian family).","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["field gentian"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Gentianella campestris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19111,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Myriopteris tomentosa, commonly known as Woolly Lip Fern, prefers to be kept on the drier side, as it is drought-tolerant and dislikes overly wet conditions. Water this plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. During active growth periods in spring and summer, you should water when the top inch of soil becomes dry. Reduce the frequency of watering in fall and winter. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. In general, it is better to underwater than overwater this tough, resilient fern."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Place Myriopteris tomentosa in a location where it will receive bright, indirect sunlight to light shade. This plant thrives in conditions that mimic its native environment, often in rocky, shaded areas. Direct, harsh sunlight can scorch the delicate fronds, so it’s best to avoid placing it in a spot with intense full sun. If growing indoors, an east or north-facing window will typically provide suitable lighting conditions. Outdoors, ensure it is sheltered from the most intense midday sun and provide some filtered light or shade during those hours."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Myriopteris tomentosa isn't always necessary unless you are trying to manage their shape or remove dead or damaged fronds. If you do prune, do so in the spring before new growth begins. Gently trim back any brown or dead fronds close to the base to allow for new, healthy growth. This can help maintain the plant's overall health and appearance. Keep in mind this fern is naturally a bit scraggly, and it's important not to remove too much foliage at once, which might stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Woolly Lipfern","description":"Myriopteris tomentosa, formerly known as Cheilanthes tomentosa is a perennial fern known as woolly lipfern. Woolly lipfern is native to the southern United States, from Pennsylvania to Arizona and Georgia, and Mexico.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Woolly Lipfern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Myriopteris tomentosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In its growing season during spring and summer, you can water it more liberally but still ensure that it doesn’t sit in water. A general rule of thumb is to water the plant once every two to four weeks, but always check that the top layer of the soil is dry before adding more water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nyctocereus serpentinus thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can tolerate some direct sunlight, especially in cooler morning hours. It's best to prune in the spring before new growth starts. Use sharp, sterilized pruning shears to make clean cuts, minimizing damage to the plant. Prune any stems that seem diseased or pest-infected to prevent the spread. It generally requires regular watering, especially during dry periods, to maintain moist but well-draining soil conditions. Overwatering should be avoided, as waterlogged soil can lead to root rot. It's best to water the plant deeply once or twice a week during the growing season, reducing frequency in the cooler months when growth slows. Ensure that the soil is consistently moist but not soggy, allowing the top layer to dry out slightly between watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leucadendron uliginosum prefers full sun, although it can tolerate partial shade. It thrives in the bright, open conditions of its native South African habitats. For optimal growth and flowering, position the plant where it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, it can benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent overheating and scorching. Adequate sunlight ensures vibrant foliage and a bountiful display of flowers. When planting in a garden or landscape, choose a location that maximizes sun exposure while protecting the plant from harsh winds and the hottest midday sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Leucadendron uliginosum is crucial for maintaining its shape and promoting healthy growth. The best time to prune is after the flowering period, in late spring or early summer. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches, cutting back to healthy, outward-facing buds. This encourages new growth and a bushier habit. Light pruning can be done throughout the growing season to maintain the desired shape and size. Avoid heavy pruning into old wood, as this can hinder the plant's ability to regenerate. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18315,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Xanthostemon chrysanthus, commonly known as the golden penda, prefers a moderate watering schedule. During the warmer months, the soil should be kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant deeply once or twice a week, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. In cooler months, reduce the frequency of watering but ensure the plant does not completely dry out. Over-watering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. Always check the soil moisture level with your finger before watering to ensure the plant's needs are met."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Xanthostemon chrysanthus thrives in full sunlight to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. In regions with extremely harsh sunlight, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. While the plant can adapt to partial shade, optimal flowering occurs with adequate sunlight exposure. Ensure it's planted in a location where it can receive good air circulation and sufficient light, which helps in reducing the risk of disease. If grown indoors, place it near a bright window where it can soak up ample natural light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Xanthostemon chrysanthus should be done to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. The best time to prune is in the late spring or early summer after the flowering season. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to improve air circulation. Cut back any overly long branches to encourage a bushier growth habit. It's also beneficial to remove any suckers or water sprouts that may divert energy from the main growth. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts and minimize stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Golden Penda","description":"Xanthostemon chrysanthus, commonly named golden penda, is a species of tree in of the Myrtaceae family, endemic to (found only in) north eastern Queensland.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Golden Penda"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Xanthostemon chrysanthus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19605,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Searsia lucida is a drought-tolerant plant commonly found in dry, sandy conditions. It requires minimal watering once established. During initial growth, it's crucial to water regularly to promote root development. Once the plant is established, reduce watering to once every couple of weeks. Ensure the soil dries out between waterings to prevent root rot. Be mindful of local climate conditions; in drier, hotter climates, it may need more frequent watering, while in cooler, moist climates, less water is necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Searsia lucida thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, provide it with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate some shade, especially in hotter climates, as long as it receives sufficient light for most of the day. In shaded areas, growth may become more sparse and less vigorous. Adjust the planting site as needed to ensure the plant receives enough light. If grown indoors, position the plant near a south or west-facing window to maximize sunlight exposure. This sunlight is crucial for healthy growth and foliage vibrance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Searsia lucida should be done lightly to maintain its natural shape and encourage bushiness. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or diseased branches to improve air circulation and prevent disease. It's also beneficial to thin out crowded branches to enhance sunlight penetration. Prune away overlapping branches to allow for better growth, but avoid over-pruning as this can stress the plant. Searsia lucida generally does not require heavy pruning due to its naturally tidy growth habit."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Glossy Currantrhus","description":"Searsia lucida, previously known as Rhus lucida, and other names varnished kuni-rhus (English) blinktaaibos (Afrikaans). This small tree has a distribution along the West Coast of South Africa from Saldanha Bay around the Cape and up the East Coast almost until the Mozambique border. Its distribution area also encompasses the whole of Kwazulu-Natal and stretches in an arm past Swaziland, right up the Lowveld areas of Mpumalanga and into Limpopo Province, almost to the Zimbabwe border....","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Glossy Currantrhus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Searsia lucida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18121,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solanum laciniatum, commonly known as the kangaroo apple, requires regular watering but with careful attention to avoid waterlogging. During the growing season in spring and summer, ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not saturated. Reduce watering in the fall and winter months when the plant is not actively growing. It's advisable to water deeply and less frequently to encourage deep root development. A well-draining soil mix will help prevent root rot by allowing excess water to drain away. Water when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solanum laciniatum thrives in a location with full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight per day for the best growth and flowering. In regions with exceptionally hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. In more temperate or cooler climates, full sun will promote vigorous growth. Ensuring the plant receives adequate light is crucial for flowering and fruiting. If growing indoors, place it near a south-facing window or provide supplemental lighting to mimic natural sunlight conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solanum laciniatum should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This will help maintain a healthy shape and encourage bushier growth. Remove any dead or damaged branches and thin out the center of the plant to improve air circulation. Avoid cutting more than a third of the plant at any one time to prevent shock. Regular pruning will help control the size and spread of the plant, as it can grow quite rapidly. When pruning, use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"kangaroo-apple","description":"Solanum laciniatum is a soft-wooded shrub native to the east coast of Australia, notably Victoria and Tasmania. It also occurs in Western Australia and New Zealand, where some authorities consider it to be introduced. It is similar to Solanum aviculare, with which it shares the common name kangaroo apple.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green to Yellow\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia","New Zealand"],"other_name":["kangaroo-apple"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Solanum laciniatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18316,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Roldana petasitis, commonly known as Velvet Groundsel, prefers well-draining soil and should be watered regularly during the growing season, typically spring and summer. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between watering to prevent root rot, as it does not tolerate overly wet conditions. During fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, as the plant enters a dormancy period where it requires much less moisture. Always ensure the pot has drainage holes, and never let the plant sit in water to ensure healthy root development and prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Roldana petasitis thrives best in a location that receives partial to full sunlight. It enjoys bright, indirect light but can also tolerate some direct sunlight, particularly morning sun, which is less intense. However, in very hot climates, it is essential to provide some protection from the harsh afternoon sun to prevent leaf scorching. When grown indoors as a houseplant, place it near a window where it can receive ample light or supplement with a grow light to ensure it flourishes. Consistent light conditions will support its lush growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Roldana petasitis is an essential practice to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. It’s best to prune this plant in early spring before the new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged stems and cut back any overly long shoots to encourage denser foliage. Regular pruning helps manage the size of the plant and stimulates new growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and avoid causing damage to the plant tissue. Sanitizing tools before use can help prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"velvet groundsel","description":"Roldana petasitis also known as velvet groundsel is a species of the genus Roldana and family Asteraceae that used to be a Senecio.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["velvet groundsel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Roldana petasitis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During dormant periods, natural lighting suffices, but the plant should not be left in complete darkness. However, removing any dead or damaged leaves will keep the plant looking tidy and prevent disease. This can be done at the end of the growing season or when leaves show signs of deterioration. Be careful while handling the plant, as all parts of it are toxic. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make cuts, and sanitize tools between uses to avoid spreading pathogens."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"autumn mandrake","description":"Mandragora autumnalis, known as mandrake or autumn mandrake, is recognized by some sources as a separate species from Mandragora officinarum, although with different circumscriptions. The large tap-roots as well as...","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Orange,Berry\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean","North Africa","Southern Europe"],"other_name":["autumn mandrake"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Root division","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Mandragora autumnalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17002,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Silphium gracile, commonly known as the slender rosinweed, requires moderate watering. It is adapted to dry conditions and can tolerate drought once established. Overwatering should be avoided as it can cause root rot. During the growing season, water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry. Ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent water from accumulating around the roots. In winter, reduce watering frequency significantly as the plant enters its dormant phase and requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Silphium gracile thrives in full sun conditions and requires a minimum of six hours of direct sunlight daily. It is a prairie plant and adapted to open, sunny environments. Planting it in full sun ensures robust flowering and overall health. While it can tolerate partial shade, lack of sufficient sunlight might lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms. Make sure to position it in a location where it won't be overshadowed by taller plants or structures, maximizing its exposure to sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Silphium gracile involves cutting back the plant to manage its shape and promote healthy growth. Remove and destroy any infected plant material to halt the spread of the rust. Regularly check plants for early signs of infection, like orange pustules on leaves, and prune these areas promptly. Ensure tools are sterilized between cuts to prevent spreading the rust to healthy parts of the plant or to other plants. This method helps in managing rust outbreaks effectively."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Groundsel crown rust","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Groundsel crown rust"],"pest_susceptibility":["Rust fungi"],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Puccinia lagenophorae"],"soil":[],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If cultivated intentionally, it's crucial to mimic its natural habitat by providing occasional moisture but avoiding excessive waterlogging. It naturally grows in a variety of lighting conditions, including full sun to shaded areas, depending on its symbiotic relationship with nearby plants. The important factor is ensuring the right environmental conditions in terms of soil and moisture to support its host plants. As it's resilient, finding the right plant companions is more crucial than directly managing its light exposure. It can assist plants in accessing nutrients across a range of sunlit environments."},{"type":"pruning","description":"As Pisolithus arhizus is a fungus rather than a traditional plant with stems and leaves, it does not require pruning in the conventional sense. There is no above-ground structure that benefits from being cut back. However, you may want to manage its growth by controlling the environment where it thrives. If growing near desired plants, ensure that it is not invading critical root space. Removal is typically managed by digging around and gently extracting the fungal body if necessary, but traditional pruning tools are not applicable here."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Dyeball","description":"Pisolithus arhizus is a widespread earth-ball like fungus, which may in fact be several closely related species. Common names include dead man's foot and dyeball. It is known in Australia as the horse dung fungus, in South Africa as perdebal, and in Europe as the Bohemian truffle. This puffball's black viscous gel is used as a natural dye for clothes. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16993,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sericocarpus linifolius, commonly known as narrowleaf aster, prefers soil that is well-drained and not overly moist. It is drought-tolerant and requires less frequent watering once established. Watering should be done deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure excess water is allowed to flow away, and the pot or planting area has good drainage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sericocarpus linifolius thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and blooming. In regions with intense heat, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from leaf scorch. Planting in an area that allows for morning sun and afternoon shade can be beneficial in particularly hot climates. Ensure the location is bright enough to prevent the plant from becoming leggy with insufficient bloom production."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sericocarpus linifolius should be done to maintain its shape and promote healthy growth. Avoid heavy pruning late in the season as this can stress the plant and affect its flowering capability in the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Narrowleaf Whitetop Aster","description":"Sericocarpus linifolius (known by the common names narrowleaf whitetop aster or flax leaf whitetop) is a perennial forb native to the eastern United States, that produces white composite flowers in summer.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Narrowleaf Whitetop Aster"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Sericocarpus linifolius"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17993,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Leucospermum oleifolium is adapted to dry conditions and should be watered sparingly. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it's important to let the soil dry out between watering sessions. During hotter months, you may need to water the plant once a week, but be sure to do it in the morning to allow moisture to evaporate if there's any excess. In cooler months, reduce watering frequency significantly, ensuring that the top few inches of soil are completely dry before watering again. Mulching can help retain moisture and maintain consistent soil temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leucospermum oleifolium thrives in environments with full sun exposure. This plant requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure healthy growth and flowering. If it's grown in a location that is too shaded, you may notice fewer blooms and leggy growth because the plant will stretch towards the light. A sunny south or west-facing spot is ideal for planting outdoors or placing the pot if grown indoors. Ensure good air circulation around the plant; this contributes to its health and vigor as well."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Leucospermum oleifolium is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy new growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before the new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged branches to improve air circulation within the plant. Cut back any lanky stems to promote a denser structure, making sure to prune above a node. Try to leave the previous year’s growth, as this is where flowers generally develop. Regular pruning also helps to enhance flowering and keep the plant manageable in size."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mix Pincushion","description":"Leucospermum oleifolium is an erect shrub of about 1 m (3.3 ft) high and 1½ m (5 ft) across that is assigned to the Proteaceae family. It has spreading branches, densely set with initially felty, entire, oval, olive-colored leaves of about 3½ cm (1½ in) long and 1½ cm (0.6 in) wide, with a bony tip that sometimes has two to five blunt teeth, with a blunt base and conspicuous veins. The flowers and their long thread-like styles...","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Mix Pincushion"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Leucospermum oleifolium"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18082,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Lindsaea linearis, commonly known as the Screw Fern, prefers consistently moist soil. However, overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot. It is advisable to water the plant regularly, ensuring the soil is evenly moist but not waterlogged. Reduced watering is necessary during the winter months when the fern’s growth slows down. Using distilled or rainwater rather than tap water is beneficial, as the latter might contain chemicals that affect the plant's health. Always ensure good drainage, and keep an eye on the humidity levels, as ferns thrive in higher humidity conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lindsaea linearis thrives in indirect or filtered light conditions. Direct sunlight can be too harsh and may scorch the delicate fronds, so it is best to place the plant in a spot where it receives bright, indirect light. An east or north-facing window is ideal for this fern. If grown outdoors, ensure it is under the shade of taller plants or trees that can filter the sunlight. In environments with low natural light, you may consider using artificial grow lights to provide adequate lighting conditions. Adjust its position as needed if you notice signs of light stress, such as fading leaf color."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Lindsaea linearis is minimal and mainly involves the removal of dead or damaged fronds. Regularly check the plant for any yellowing or browning fronds and trim them near the base using clean, sharp scissors. This not only improves the fern's appearance but also encourages new growth. Pruning is best done during the growing season, typically spring through early fall. Avoid cutting healthy fronds as pruning living parts unnecessarily can stress the plant. Additionally, ensure your tools are sterilized to prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Screw Fern","description":"Lindsaea linearis is known as the screw fern, as the fronds may have a twisting appearance. A small fern of widespread distribution in many parts of Australia. Found in a variety of habitats, often near swamps or moist places. By rocks, heathland or open forest. It has a dark stem, unlike the similar necklace fern, which is green.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Australia","New Zealand"],"other_name":["Screw Fern"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Lindsaea linearis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loam"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Be cautious not to overwater, as Phlox amoena does not thrive in soggy conditions and excessive moisture can lead to root rot. A layer of mulch can help retain moisture and maintain an even soil temperature. Watering in the morning is ideal to allow the foliage to dry, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phlox amoena thrives in full sun locations, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to perform at its best and produce vibrant blooms. When planting Phlox amoena, choose a site that receives morning sun and afternoon shade if your garden is particularly warm. Ensure the plant is not overshadowed by taller plants to allow it to receive adequate sunlight throughout the day for optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phlox amoena is essential to encourage bushier growth and more blooms. Deadhead spent blooms regularly to promote continuous flowering throughout the growing season. In late autumn or early spring, cut back the stems to ground level to encourage new growth and help tidy up the garden. During the growing season, if any stems become excessively long or leggy, trim them back to maintain a compact and attractive shape. Regular pruning also helps to improve air circulation through the plant, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"hairy phlox","description":"Phlox amoena, commonly called hairy phlox, is a flowering plant in the Phlox family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16402,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ferocactus emoryi, like most cacti, requires well-draining soil and does not need frequent watering. Water the plant thoroughly, allowing water to soak through the soil and excess to drain away. Then, allow the soil to dry out completely before watering again, especially during the growing season in spring and summer. In its dormant period during fall and winter, reduce watering to once a month or even less, only enough to prevent the plant from shriveling. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is crucial to err on the side of underwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ferocactus emoryi thrives in full sunlight conditions, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day. It is well-adapted to very bright and hot environments, typical of desert habitats. Indoor placement should be near a south-facing window where it can receive ample direct sunlight. If growing outdoors, choose a spot that receives plenty of sunshine. In inadequate lighting conditions, the cactus may etiolate, meaning it will stretch out and weaken as it seeks more light, negatively impacting its appearance and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ferocactus emoryi is minimal and mainly involves removing old or damaged parts. Dead or yellowing parts should be gently cut back using clean, sharp tools to prevent any disease. Since this cactus has sharp spines, care should be taken to protect your hands during pruning activities. Avoid cutting into the main stem of the plant, as this can introduce pathogens and harm the cactus. Pruning primarily promotes better air circulation around the plant and keeps its appearance tidy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Emory's barrel cactus","description":"Ferocactus emoryi, known commonly as Emory's barrel cactus, Coville's barrel cactus and traveler's friend, is a barrel cactus in the genus Ferocactus.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Emory's barrel cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Ferocactus emoryi"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17601,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Inga vera, commonly known as Ice Cream Bean, thrives best in well-drained soil with consistent moisture. Its watering needs are moderate; it should be watered regularly during the growing season to keep the soil slightly moist but not waterlogged. Inga vera is somewhat drought-tolerant once established, but young plants require frequent watering. It's crucial to reduce watering during the winter dormancy phase to prevent root rot. Ensure that the plant is never left standing in water, as this can be harmful."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Inga vera prefers full sun to thrive, but it can tolerate partial shade, especially in the hottest climates. For optimal growth and fruit production, it should receive at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day. If grown in areas with intense heat, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorching. When planting, choose a location that provides ample sunlight and ensure the plant is not shaded by larger trees or structures. As a tropical plant, Inga vera appreciates warmth and a bright environment for best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Inga vera is typically done to encourage a strong structure and to shape the plant. The best time to prune is in the late winter or early spring, before the plant starts its new growth. Remove any dead or diseased branches, as well as those that are crossing or rubbing against each other. This helps improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, benefiting the plant's health. Light pruning can also be done to control the size of the plant and promote bushier growth, but avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"river koko","description":"Inga edulis (eng. ice-cream-bean, joaquiniquil, Mex. cuaniquil, guama or guaba) is a fruit native to South America. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even light exposure and maintain its symmetrical growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Austrocylindropuntia subulata is generally not necessary, but it can be done to maintain the plant’s size and shape or to remove any damaged or diseased segments. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to cut segments at the base, especially if they are turning brown or soft. Always wear gloves when handling this plant, as its needles can be quite sharp. Pruning also encourages new growth, so if the plant becomes leggy or sparse, trimming back some of the stems can stimulate a fuller appearance. In its natural habitat, this plant thrives on minimal water, so it's best to mimic those conditions in cultivation by maintaining a restrained watering schedule."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oenothera serrulata thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and blooming. Insufficient sunlight can result in reduced flowering and leggy growth, as the plant stretches towards available light sources. If planting in a garden, choose a south-facing or unobstructed area to maximize exposure to sunlight. In particularly hot climates, a bit of afternoon shade can prevent scorching, but generally, full sun is ideal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not usually necessary for Oenothera serrulata, but it can be beneficial for managing its shape and encouraging healthy growth. During the growing season, which typically spans from spring to early fall, water the cactus thoroughly but allow the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. This usually translates to watering approximately every two to four weeks, depending on climate and humidity levels. In winter, reduce waterings significantly or cease altogether, as the plant enters a period of dormancy. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's essential to use well-draining soil and avoid letting the cactus sit in water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ferocactus wislizeni thrives in full sunlight. Provide it with at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. This cactus prefers bright, unfiltered light, typical of its native desert habitat. If kept indoors, place it near a south-facing window where it can receive abundant sunlight. In regions with extremely hot summers, some light afternoon shade can help prevent scorching, but generally, more sun promotes better growth and flowering. If moving from indoors to outdoors, acclimate the plant gradually to prevent sunburn by slowly increasing its exposure to direct sunlight over a week or two."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ferocactus wislizeni is generally unnecessary, as it naturally maintains its shape and size. However, you can remove any dead or damaged spines, or clean up the base by removing dried lower parts of the plant. This helps prevent pests and disease. If the cactus becomes top-heavy or develops offsets, you can cut these off at the base using clean, sharp tools. Allow any wounds on the plant to callous over before returning it to its spot, which helps prevent infection. Remember to wear thick gloves while handling due to the plant's sharp spines."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"fishhook barrel cactus","description":"Ferocactus wislizeni, the fishhook barrel cactus, also called Arizona barrel cactus, candy barrel cactus, and Southwestern barrel cactus, is a species of flowering plant in the cactus family Cactaceae, native to northern Mexico and the southern United States. It is a ball-shaped cactus eventually growing to a cylindrical shape, with spiny ribs and red or yellow flowers in summer.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["fishhook barrel cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Ferocactus wislizeni"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Maintaining this environment will support its growth and sustainability, mimicking its natural conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for lichens such as Sticta latifrons. Lichens grow slowly and do not have leaves, stems, or roots like vascular plants. Avoid aggressive pruning or the use of tools that might disturb the substrate to which the lichen is attached. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17694,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Wedelia hispida prefers a moderate watering schedule. It thrives best when the soil is allowed to dry between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to ensure good drainage and avoid soggy soil conditions. During the growing seasons of spring and summer, increase the watering frequency, but reduce it in the cooler months. Always check the moisture level of the soil by inserting your finger about an inch deep - if it feels dry, it's time to water. This plant can tolerate some drought but will show its best growth with consistent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Wedelia hispida thrives in full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, it is best to provide at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight a day. In regions with extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from scorching. Insufficient sunlight can lead to reduced flowering and a leggy, sparse appearance. When grown indoors or in less sunny spots, consider supplementing with a grow light to ensure the plant receives enough light for healthy growth. Position it in a south-facing window for maximum light exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is essential for maintaining the shape and promoting the health of Wedelia hispida. Regularly trim back any leggy or overgrown stems to encourage bushier growth. Prune after the flowering season to remove spent blooms and any dead or damaged branches. This will not only help in maintaining a tidy appearance but also prevent the plant from becoming too woody. Remove any diseased foliage immediately to stop the spread of potential issues. For the best results, use sharp, sterilized pruning shears, and try to make cuts above a leaf node or bud to stimulate new growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Texas creeping-oxeye","description":"Wedelia acapulcensis, commonly known as Acapulco wedelia, is a species of flowering plant in the sunflower family, Asteraceae. It is crucial to prevent the plant from drying out entirely; therefore, water regularly but ensure the soil is well-draining to avoid waterlogging. Ensure the plant receives enough indirect light to facilitate healthy development and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Chiloglottis valida involves removing dead or withered leaves and flowers to encourage healthy growth and prevent disease. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18407,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Arachis duranensis, a wild peanut plant, requires moderate watering. It is crucial to maintain a balance as the plant enjoys evenly moist soil but is susceptible to root rot if waterlogged. Water the plant thoroughly to allow the water to reach its deep root system and then let the topsoil dry out before watering again. Seasonal adjustments are necessary, reducing watering in cooler, dormant seasons and increasing during active growth periods. Be mindful of the plant's environment; potted soils may dry faster and may need more frequent watering compared to ground-grown plants."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arachis duranensis thrives best with full sun exposure, which means it should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. This ensures optimal growth and promotes flowering. However, it can also tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, where afternoon shade can protect the plant from extreme heat and prevent leaf scorching. If growing indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window that gets plenty of natural light. Regularly rotate the plant to ensure even sunlight distribution on all sides, preventing uneven growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Arachis duranensis is minimal but can boost plant health and encourage a bushier growth habit. Regularly inspect the plant and remove any dead or diseased leaves to improve air circulation and minimize the risk of fungal diseases. In early spring, lightly prune the tips of the plant to encourage branching and a more compact shape. Be careful not to over-prune as this can stress the plant. Always use sharp, sterile tools to prevent the spread of disease. Pruning is also a good opportunity to check for pests and other issues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wild Peanut","description":"Arachis duranensis (syn. Arachis argentinensis Speg., Arachis spegazzinii M.Gregory & W.Gregory) is a herb found in South America, specially Argentina, Bolivia, and Paraguay. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16404,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Festuca gigantea, commonly known as giant fescue grass, prefers a moderately moist environment. Watering should be done regularly to keep the soil consistently damp, especially during dry spells in summer. However, it is important to ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging. The plant is somewhat drought-tolerant once established, but young plants require more frequent watering. A good practice is to water deeply and allow the topsoil to dry out slightly between waterings, to encourage deep root growth and a more drought-resistant plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Festuca gigantea thrives best in sites that receive full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should get at least 4-6 hours of direct sunlight each day to flourish. While it can tolerate some shade, too much can lead to leggy and weak growth. The plant is adaptable to various light conditions but performs best with adequate sunlight, which helps in maintaining its compact, dense form. If planted in an overly shaded area, the foliage might become sparse, and the plant may not perform optimally, impacting its vigor and growth habit."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Festuca gigantea is generally straightforward and mainly involves cleaning up dead or damaged foliage. In late winter or early spring, before new growth appears, cut back any old or tatty leaves to maintain a tidy appearance and encourage healthy new growth. You can trim back to ground level if necessary. If the plant is used in a meadow or as ornamental grass in a landscape, occasional mowing or cutting back can help control its size and prevent flowering if desired. Regular cutting will also prevent self-seeding and help maintain its shape."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Giant Fescue","description":"Festuca gigantea, or giant fescue, is a plant species in the Poaceae (grass family). Because this and other members of Festuca subgenus Schedonorus have more in common morphologically with members of the genus Lolium than with Festuca and often produce fertile hybrids with other Lolium species, Festuca gigantea has been recently published as Lolium giganteum (L.) Darbysh. (1993) and then as Schedonorus giganteus (L.) Holub (1998). Sources vary as to which placement is more acceptable.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Giant Fescue"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Festuca gigantea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17402,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fouquieria columnaris, commonly known as the Boojum tree, is adapted to arid conditions and requires very little water. During its growing season in spring and early summer, water it lightly to maintain slight soil moisture, but ensure the soil dries out thoroughly between waterings to prevent root rot. In the dormant winter months, reduce watering significantly, allowing the plant to remain mostly dry. Overwatering can be detrimental, so mimic its natural desert habitat by prioritizing drainage and infrequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Boojum tree thrives in full sun conditions, mimicking the bright, intense sunlight of its native desert habitat. It should receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. Plant it in a location where it won’t be overshadowed by larger plants or structures, as insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and poor plant health. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent sunburned foliage, especially for younger plants. Always ensure good airflow around the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Fouquieria columnaris is minimal, as it naturally develops a unique form over time. Prune only to remove dead or damaged branches, ideally in late winter or early spring, before new growth starts. Use clean, sharp pruning tools to make clean cuts, which help prevent disease. Avoid heavy pruning, as it can disrupt the plant’s natural structure. Always step back and assess the form of the tree before you cut, and try to maintain its distinctive silhouette, which is part of its charm and appeal."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Boojum tree","description":"Fouquieria columnaris, the Boojum tree or cirio (American Spanish: ) is a tree in the ocotillo family, whose other members include the ocotillos. It is nearly endemic to the Baja California Peninsula (both the northern and southern states), with only a small population in the Sierra Bacha of Sonora, Mexico. The plant's English name, Boojum, was given by Godfrey Sykes of the Desert Laboratory in Tucson, Arizona and is taken from Lewis Carroll's poem \"The Hunting of...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Boojum tree"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Fouquieria columnaris"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18507,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Melicytus lanceolatus, commonly known as the coastal mahoe, thrives in environments with moderate watering needs. It's important to allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings, as overly damp soil can lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply but infrequently, especially during its active growing season in spring and summer, ensuring water drains well to prevent waterlogging. During the cooler months of fall and winter, reduce the frequency of watering, allowing natural rainfall to assist if the plant is outdoors. Always adjust watering based on humidity and temperature to maintain optimal soil moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Melicytus lanceolatus prefers a location with full sunlight to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight per day to thrive and maintain its natural vigor. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure is beneficial for optimal growth and flowering. In overly shaded areas, the plant may experience reduced growth and fewer blooms. Protect it from harsh afternoon sun in extremely hot climates to prevent leaf scorch. Monitoring the plant's light exposure and adjusting its location if necessary can ensure it receives the appropriate amount of sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Melicytus lanceolatus is not typically required unless you're managing its shape or size. Early spring is the best time to prune, before the new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote healthy growth. You can also prune to encourage a bushier form by cutting back the tips of the stems. The plant can tolerate moderate pruning, but avoid heavy cutting, as it could stress the plant. Regular light pruning can keep the plant tidy and maintain its ornamental appearance, particularly in cultivated landscapes."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Māhoe Wao","description":"Melicytus lanceolatus, commonly called Narrow-leaved māhoe or māhoe-wao, is a small tree of the family Violaceae endemic to New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Blue\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia","New Zealand"],"other_name":["Māhoe Wao"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Melicytus lanceolatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Evening"}}

It's important to keep the soil evenly moist, especially during the growing season, but avoid waterlogging as it can lead to root rot. During dry spells, increase watering frequency to maintain adequate moisture levels. Once established, Solidago ohioensis can tolerate short periods of drought, but it will thrive with regular watering to support its growth and flowering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives best in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. Ohio goldenrod can tolerate partial shade, but this may result in less vigorous growth and reduced flowering. Planting it in a sunny location helps ensure a robust display of its bright yellow flowers. Full sun exposure also helps prevent the plant from becoming leggy and supports healthy development of its dense, bushy form."},{"type":"pruning","description":"For Solidago ohioensis, pruning is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This involves cutting back the previous season's stems to the base to encourage new, vigorous growth. Throughout the growing season, deadheading spent flowers can also help prolong the blooming period and prevent unwanted self-seeding. Pruning not only helps in maintaining the plant's shape and health but also reduces the spread of any potential plant diseases by improving air circulation."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Ohio Goldenrod","description":"Solidago ohioensis is a North American plant species in the sunflower family, called the Ohio goldenrod. It is important to water this plant regularly to maintain its natural habitat conditions. However, avoid waterlogging by ensuring the soil has proper drainage. During the growing season, water the plant thoroughly whenever the top inch of the soil feels dry. In its native tropical environment, this plant usually receives ample rainfall, so mimicking these conditions with regular watering can promote healthy growth. During the drier seasons or when grown indoors, consider misting the plant to increase humidity levels. Adjust watering frequency based on the plant's growth stage and environmental conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lasianthus attenuatus thrives in partial to full shade conditions, making it ideal for understory planting in gardens or low-light indoor spaces. It is adapted to forest environments where it receives dappled sunlight, so it prefers indirect or filtered light. Direct sunlight, especially harsh afternoon sun, should be avoided as it can scorch the leaves and impair the plant's health. When grown indoors, placing it near a north or east-facing window where it can receive gentle morning sun works well. If natural light is insufficient, consider using artificial grow lights to supplement lighting needs."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Lasianthus attenuatus is generally minimal and primarily revolves around maintaining its shape and removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Inspect the plant regularly and use clean, sharp pruning shears to cut back any problematic stems. Pruning can also help control its size if it becomes too large for the available space. To encourage a bushier growth habit, occasionally prune the tips of the branches. This plant responds well to light pruning, so heavy pruning is not recommended as it may stress the plant or hinder its growth. Spring is the best time for any major pruning tasks. Regularly check that the surrounding soil or water is not becoming stagnant, which can promote root rot or other diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Kandelia obovata thrives best under full sunlight conditions. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18115,"attracts":["bees","butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Justicia carnea, also known as the Brazilian Plume Flower, prefers consistently moist soil, so regular watering is essential, especially during the growing season from spring to early fall. While it enjoys moisture, it’s important to avoid waterlogged conditions that could lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. During the winter months, reduce the frequency of watering while maintaining sufficient humidity levels around the plant by misting or placing a tray of water nearby to ensure it doesn’t dry out too much."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This tropical plant thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can tolerate some full sun, especially in cooler climates. However, too much direct sunlight, particularly in hot afternoons, can scorch the leaves. It’s ideally placed in a spot where it receives morning sun and afternoon shade. Indoors, it does well in a room with plenty of natural light, perhaps near an east or north-facing window. During winter, when light levels can be lower, you may want to move it to a sunnier spot to ensure it gets enough light to thrive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Justicia carnea is recommended to maintain a bushy, compact shape and encourage new growth. Prune in early spring before new growth begins, by cutting back the stems to about half their size. This encourages the development of more branches, resulting in a fuller plant. Remove any dead or damaged foliage throughout the year to keep the plant healthy. Light trimming can also be done after the blooming period to remove spent flowers and tidying up the shape, which might stimulate another round of blooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"King's-crown","description":"Justicia carnea, with common names including Brazilian plume flower, Brazilian-plume, flamingo flower, and jacobinia — is a flowering plant in the family Acanthaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Brazil","South America"],"other_name":["King's-crown"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider Mites","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Justicia carnea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17996,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erica cerinthoides, also known as the Fire Heath, prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil. It thrives with regular watering, especially during its active growing season in spring and summer. Allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Reduce watering during fall and winter when the plant's growth slows down. The plant benefits from well-draining soil and a pot with drainage holes to ensure excess water does not accumulate, which can lead to root diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erica cerinthoides prefers full sunlight to partial shade. It thrives in environments where it can receive direct sunlight for most of the day, mimicking its natural habitat. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can soak in the sun's rays. However, in extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade might prevent leaf scorch. This balance of light helps the plant produce vibrant blooms and maintain its health. Ensuring it gets the right amount of sunlight is crucial for its flowering and overall growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erica cerinthoides is straightforward and helps maintain its shape and fuller growth. Prune immediately after flowering to avoid cutting off next season's blooms. Remove spent flowers and trim any dead or diseased wood to encourage healthy new growth. Light trimming of leggy stems can also promote a bushier plant. Use clean, sharp shears to make cuts just above a leaf node, which will spur new growth.
