It is important not to over-water this plant; water it only when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During prolonged dry periods, you may water it more frequently, but ensure that the soil has good drainage to prevent root rot. Consistent, heavy watering is not necessary, as this plant is well-adapted to infrequent moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pilosella officinarum thrives in full sun conditions and is well-suited to open, sunny areas. It requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to grow vigorously and produce abundant blooms. While it can tolerate partial shade, extended periods without full sun may reduce flowering and foliage density. If grown in a shadier spot, the plant may become leggy and less attractive. Therefore, for optimal growth and profuse blooming, ensure it is situated where it can soak up plenty of sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pilosella officinarum involves trimming the plant to control its spread and encourage healthy growth. This can be done in late winter or early spring. Cut back any dead or damaged stems to improve the plant's appearance and vitality. It's also beneficial to remove flowering stems after the blooms fade to prevent seed dispersal, which can lead to invasive growth. Regular mowing or trimming in the growing season can help maintain the plant's compact shape and prevent it from overtaking garden spaces."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"mouse-eared hawkweed","description":"Hieracium pilosella (syn. Pilosella officinarum), known as mouse-ear hawkweed, is a yellow-flowered species of flowering plant in the daisy family Asteraceae, native to Europe and northern Asia. It produces single, lemon-coloured inflorescences. It is an allelopathic plant. Like most hawkweed species, it is highly variable and is a member of a species complex of several dozens of subspecies and hundreds of varieties and forms.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["mouse-eared hawkweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Rhizome division"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Pilosella officinarum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Chalky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18408,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Viola calcarata, commonly known as the horned pansy, requires moderate watering to thrive. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. It is best to water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Be cautious during the hot summer months, as the soil can dry out more quickly. However, make sure to reduce watering during the winter months when the plant is dormant. Overwatering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot, while underwatering may cause the leaves to wilt and flowers to drop prematurely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viola calcarata thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth and flowering, it is best to provide them with around 4 to 6 hours of sunlight each day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the flowers from scorching. If grown in containers, try to place them where they can receive direct morning sunlight followed by dappled shade as the day progresses. Too much shade can result in fewer blooms, while too much direct sun might cause leaf burn, so a balance is essential for healthy plants."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viola calcarata is relatively simple and mainly involves deadheading spent flowers to encourage continuous blooming throughout the growing season. This can also help prevent the plant from self-seeding if that is not desired. Cut the flower stems down to the base after the flowers wilt and fade. In addition, remove any dead or damaged leaves to maintain the plant's overall health and appearance. At the end of the growing season, you can trim back the plant lightly to prepare it for winter dormancy, which may help promote more vigorous growth in spring."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Long-spurred Violet","description":"Viola calcarata is a species of genus Viola that grows on mountains of south-eastern Europe. It is commonly known as long-spurred violet or mountain violet. During the growing season, which is primarily spring through fall, keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. It's important to reduce watering in winter when the plant is dormant. Overwatering during dormancy can lead to bulb rot. Always ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to avoid standing water, which can be detrimental to its health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in full sun to partial shade. Zephyranthes carinata requires a minimum of 6 hours of sunlight per day to bloom optimally. If grown indoors, place it in the brightest spot or near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample direct sunlight. In shadier locations, the plant may produce fewer flowers, so ensuring adequate light exposure is key to healthy growth and prolific blooming. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade may protect the plant from scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Zephyranthes carinata is minimal and mostly involves deadheading. Remove spent flowers by cutting the flower stalks down to the base to encourage more blooms and prevent seed formation. This also helps the plant to focus its energy on growth and bulb development. If the foliage becomes unsightly or damaged, you can tidy the plant by trimming off any yellow or brown leaves. However, do not remove healthy green leaves, as they are crucial for photosynthesis and replenishing the bulb's energy stores."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Rose Pink Zephyr Lily","description":"Zephyranthes carinata, commonly known as the rosepink zephyr lily or pink rain lily, is a perennial flowering plant native to Mexico, Colombia and Central America. It is also widely cultivated as an ornamental and naturalized in the West Indies, Peru, Argentina, Brazil, the southeastern United States from Texas to Florida, Zimbabwe, South Africa, China, Korea, the Ryukyu Islands, Assam, Nepal, Bhutan, Sri Lanka, Solomon Islands, Queensland, Society Islands, Kiribati, and Caroline Islands.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Guatemala"],"other_name":["Rose Pink Zephyr Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulbs"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Zephyranthes carinata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17696,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Echinocereus dasyacanthus, commonly known as the Texas Rainbow Cactus, requires careful watering to prevent root rot. Water the cactus thoroughly during its active growing season in spring and summer, allowing the soil to dry completely between waterings. Ensure the pot has drainage holes to avoid waterlogging. During fall and winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant enters dormancy. Depending on humidity levels, you might only need to water it once every few weeks during this period. Remember that less is more when it comes to watering cacti."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Echinocereus dasyacanthus thrives in bright, direct sunlight and should receive at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight a day. Position the cactus in a south or west-facing window to ensure it gets ample light. If natural light is insufficient, especially during the winter months, consider supplementing with a grow light. Without enough light, the cactus may become elongated or etiolated. Gradually adapt the plant to any changes in light conditions to prevent sunburn, especially if moving it outdoors during the warmer months."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Echinocereus dasyacanthus is generally minimal but can be beneficial for removing dead or damaged stems which can help maintain the plant's health. If your cactus grows some offsets you don't want, these can also be pruned and repotted if desired. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to make cuts, and try to avoid cutting into healthy green areas. Allow the cut areas to callus over before watering again, as this helps prevent infections or disease. Always wear protective gloves to avoid injury from the cactus spines."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Texas rainbow cactus","description":"Echinocereus dasyacanthus is a member of the cactus family, Cactaceae. It is one of about 2000 total species belonging to this family. The cactus is commonly known as Texas rainbow cactus because of the subtle rings or bands of contrasting colors along the stem of the plant. Not all Texas rainbow cacti have the \"rainbow\" coloration on their stems. Another common name is spiny hedgehog cactus.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Texas rainbow cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Echinocereus dasyacanthus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In regions with intense sunlight, providing afternoon shade can help maintain leaf color and prevent stress. Indoors, a location near a south or west-facing window is ideal, but during very sunny days, sheer curtains may be used to filter the light adequately."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mandevilla macrosiphon is essential for maintaining its shape and promoting vigorous growth. The best time to prune is early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to cut back each stem, reducing about one-third of its length to encourage branching and fullness. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems at the base. Throughout the growing season, occasional light pruning can help maintain its desired shape and support blooming. Wearing gloves is advisable to avoid contact with the sap, which can be irritating to the skin."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"plateau rocktrumpet","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["plateau rocktrumpet"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider mites","Aphids"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Mandevilla macrosiphon"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19205,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vachellia karroo, also known as Sweet Thorn, is a drought-tolerant plant that doesn't require frequent watering once established. It thrives in well-drained soil, and overwatering can lead to root rot. During its establishment period, water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. In general, watering once every two weeks during dry periods is sufficient for mature plants. Always adjust based on the climate and rainfall of your area. Avoid watering in the rainy season unless there are extended dry spells."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vachellia karroo thrives in full sun conditions, requiring plenty of direct sunlight throughout the day to maintain its growth and health. Ideally, it should be planted in a location that receives at least six to eight hours of sunlight daily. Partial shade can be tolerated, but the plant may not flower as profusely or vigorously under such conditions. Ensure the site is open and receives unobstructed sunlight, which will also help in minimizing moisture accumulation and thus reduce disease susceptibility during wet seasons."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vachellia karroo should be done to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is during the dormant winter months. This will help stimulate growth in the spring. Use clean, sharp tools to make cuts near the branch collar to promote good healing. Minimal pruning is typically needed for aesthetic purposes or to keep pathways clear. Be cautious of the thorns when pruning and take care to create an open, well-ventilated canopy to improve air circulation and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sweet Thorn","description":"Vachellia karroo, commonly known as the Sweet thorn, is a species of acacia, native to southern Africa from southern Angola east to Mozambique, and south to South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Southern Africa"],"other_name":["Sweet Thorn"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Vachellia karroo"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19106,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Myriopteris lanosa, commonly known as the Woolly Lip Fern, prefers to be kept in consistently moist soil, but not soggy. It's important to allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season in spring and summer, water when the soil feels dry to the touch. In the fall and winter, you can reduce watering frequency as the plant's growth slows down. Always use lukewarm water and ensure the plant is in a pot with adequate drainage to avoid waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Myriopteris lanosa thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. Direct sunlight can scorch its delicate fronds, so it's best to place the plant near a window where it can receive filtered light or in a spot that gets dappled sunlight. If growing outdoors, the Woolly Lip Fern prefers a partially shaded area, especially filtered light through trees or a location that receives morning sun. Avoid placing it in deep shade as this can hinder its growth. During the winter months, ensure the plant still receives adequate light, moving it to a brighter spot if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not extensively required for Myriopteris lanosa, but occasional maintenance can help keep it looking tidy and healthy. Remove any dead or damaged fronds by cutting them at the base with sterilized scissors. This not only improves the appearance but also prevents the spread of disease. You can also trim away any overly long or wayward fronds to maintain the plant's shape. Take care to avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the plant. Late winter or early spring is the best time for pruning just before new growth appears."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hairy Lip Fern","description":"Myriopteris lanosa, the hairy lip fern, is a moderately-sized fern of the eastern United States, a member of the family Pteridaceae. Its leaves and stem are sparsely covered in hairs, but lack scales, hence its common name. One of the cheilanthoid ferns, it was usually classified in the genus Cheilanthes until 2013, when the genus Myriopteris was again recognized as separate from Cheilanthes. It typically grows in shallow, dry, soil, often in rocky habitats.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Hairy Lip Fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation","Division"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Myriopteris lanosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18086,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salix lanata, commonly known as the Woolly Willow, requires consistent moisture to thrive, especially during its growing season. It prefers soil that is slightly damp, but care should be taken to avoid waterlogging, which can cause root rot. Watering should be adjusted based on seasonal changes; during the warmer months, the plant will need more frequent watering to maintain adequate soil moisture levels. In contrast, during the colder months, watering can be reduced. Always check the top layer of soil and water when it feels dry to the touch, ensuring bottom drainage is adequate."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salix lanata thrives best in full sun to partial shade conditions. It prefers at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to promote healthy foliage and growth. If grown indoors or in areas where full sun isn't consistently available, it can tolerate some partial shade, but growth might be slightly reduced. When positioning this plant in your garden, ensure it is placed where it won't be shaded by larger plants or structures for extended periods. Providing ample sunlight is essential for the plant to maintain its vibrant leaves and woolly appearance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salix lanata should be done in late winter or early spring, before the onset of new growth. This encourages a dense and bushy form. The primary focus should be on removing dead, diseased, or damaged branches to maintain the plant's health. Additionally, you may thin out older branches to promote better air circulation within the plant, which helps reduce the risk of fungal diseases. Care should be taken to use clean, sharp pruning tools and to make cuts at an angle just above a growth node to encourage optimal regrowth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Woolly Willow","description":"Salix lanata, the woolly willow, is a subarctic species of willow native to Iceland, the Faeroes, northern Scandinavia, Finland, through to eastern Siberia. In Scotland it can be found in only a few localities of Perthshire, Angus and Aberdeen, generally on rocky mountain sides at altitudes between 600–900 m (1,969–2,953 ft).","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Woolly Willow"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Willow leaf beetle"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Salix lanata"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17403,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Thamnolia vermicularis, commonly known as whiteworm lichen, typically does not require watering when grown outdoors as it is well-adapted to absorbing moisture from the air. If you are cultivating it in a controlled environment, such as a terrarium, ensure a high humidity level by misting occasionally. However, avoid direct watering to prevent waterlogging or fungal issues. Keep the surrounding substrate slightly moist and monitor the lichen's appearance; shriveled conditions could indicate a need for more humidity. Overall, focus on maintaining environmental moisture over direct watering practices."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thamnolia vermicularis thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It is adapted to high-altitude, UV-rich environments and can tolerate varying light conditions, but direct, harsh sunlight should be avoided as it can lead to desiccation. If kept in a terrarium or indoors, placing it in a well-lit area where it can receive consistent but indirect light is ideal. If light levels are insufficient, consider using a grow light to provide adequate luminosity. Optimal exposure will ensure healthy growth and coloration, mimicking its natural habitat conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is generally unnecessary for Thamnolia vermicularis. This species of lichen has a natural growth pattern that maintains its compact and wiry form. If any part of the lichen becomes damaged or discolored, you can gently remove these sections to promote overall health and appearance. It’s important to handle the lichen with care, as it is delicate and can be easily crushed. Regularly inspecting the lichen for dead or unhealthy sections and removing them will help in maintaining a clean and thriving specimen."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Thamnolia Lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Arctic","Alpine areas"],"other_name":["Thamnolia Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Thamnolia vermicularis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18211,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Anchusa undulata, commonly known as the wavy-leaved alkanet, prefers well-drained soil and does not like to sit in wet conditions. During the growing season, water the plant moderately and allow the soil to dry between waterings. Ensure you're not over-watering as this can lead to root rot. Reduce watering in the dormant season, as the plant requires less moisture. It's important to tailor your watering schedule based on your climate, as this plant is more drought-tolerant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Anchusa undulata thrives in full sun conditions. It requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth and bloom. While the plant can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure will ensure more vibrant and abundant flowers. In overly shaded areas, the plant might become leggy and produce fewer blooms. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window for maximum sunlight, and consider supplementing with grow lights if needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Anchusa undulata mainly involves removing spent flowers to promote continued blooming and to prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively, which it can do quite easily. Cut back the flowering stems as they finish, which will also help maintain a tidy appearance. At the end of the growing season, you can cut the plant back to the ground, which encourages healthy growth for the following year. Regular pruning helps maintain its form and encourages bushier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Undulate Alkanet","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["Undulate Alkanet"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf miners"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Anchusa undulata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18608,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Salvia aurea, commonly known as golden sage, requires regular watering to thrive. It prefers the soil to dry out slightly between waterings, so it's important to ensure the top inch of the soil is dry before watering again. During the growing season, it should be watered more frequently, especially if planted in well-draining soil or containers, as they dry out faster. In the winter, the watering frequency should be reduced as plant growth slows. Be cautious not to overwater, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Salvia aurea thrives in full sunlight and benefits from at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. It is essential for the plant's growth and flowering. While it can tolerate some light shade, too little sun may lead to leggy growth and fewer flowers. If planted indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window to ensure it receives ample light. In hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching, but overall, maximizing sun exposure is ideal for Salvia aurea."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Salvia aurea is essential to encourage bushy growth and more blooms. It's best to prune in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems and thin out crowded areas to improve air circulation. After the first flush of blooms, deadhead spent flowers to promote additional flowering. Cut back the plant by about one-third after the blooming period to keep it tidy and encourage new growth. Regular pruning throughout the growing season helps maintain the plant's shape and vigor."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Brown Sage","description":"Salvia africana-lutea (beach salvia, dune salvia, golden salvia, bruin- of sandsalie, geelblomsalie) is a shrubby evergreen perennial native to coastal sand dunes and hills on the coast of the Cape Province in South Africa. It has numerous woody stems growing to more than 1 m in height and width, with sparse grey-green leaves. The flowers start out as a bright yellow, turning into a rusty color, with the dark rusty-colored calyx persisting long after fruiting begins.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Brown Sage"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Salvia aurea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18311,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Tulipa agenensis requires moderate watering. It is essential to water the plant sparingly during its growing season, ensuring that the soil remains slightly moist but not waterlogged. Overwatering can rot the bulbs, so allow the top couple of inches of soil to dry out before watering again. Reduce watering in the dormancy period after the plant has bloomed and the leaves begin to yellow. This species is drought-tolerant once established, but regular watering during active growth will support vibrant blooms and healthy foliage."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Tulipa agenensis thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. This is especially important in the flowering period as ample sunlight supports vibrant blooms and healthy growth. In its natural habitat, it usually experiences a hot, sunny climate, so planting it in a spot that receives a lot of sun will mimic these conditions. If planting in a hotter climate, some afternoon shade can help prevent excessive heat stress and prolong blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tulipa agenensis is a straightforward process. After blooming, the flowers can be deadheaded by removing spent blooms to direct the plant's energy back to the bulb rather than seed production. However, keep the foliage intact until it withers, as the leaves photosynthesize and provide energy to the bulb for the next growing season. Once the leaves have yellowed and died back naturally, they can be pruned away. This allows the plant to complete its growth cycle and ensures robust growth in the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Eyed Tulip","description":"Tulipa agenensis is a Middle Eastern species of flowering plants in the family Liliaceae. It is native to Turkey, Iran, Cyprus, the Aegean Islands, Syria, Lebanon, Israel, Jordan, and Palestine, and naturalized in the central and western Mediterranean (Italy, Tunisia, France, Portugal, Moldova etc.).","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Middle East","Eastern Mediterranean"],"other_name":["Eyed Tulip"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Tulipa agenensis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Light pruning may also help you maintain a desired shape or size, as the Chinese fringetree can naturally develop a slightly irregular form as it matures."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tassel Tree","description":"Chionanthus retusus (Chinese Fringetree; Chinese: 流蘇樹 liúsūshù) is a species of Chionanthus native to eastern Asia, in eastern and central China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Dark blue\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["China","Korea"],"other_name":["Tassel Tree"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Chionanthus retusus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16997,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sida abutifolia, commonly known as spreading fanpetals or prostrate sida, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering once established. It is best to water the plant deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues, so ensure the plant is in well-draining soil. Typically, watering every two weeks or so during dry spells is sufficient. In cooler months or when rainfall is adequate, reduce watering further."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sida abutifolia prefers full sunlight but can tolerate partial shade conditions. For optimal growth, place the plant in a location where it can receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. In areas with very hot climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. Lack of sunlight can lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms. Thus, ensuring adequate sunlight exposure is crucial for vibrant foliage and a healthy flowering cycle, making full sun locations the best choice for this plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sida abutifolia is generally minimal and primarily done to maintain its shape and remove dead or damaged growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18409,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ranunculus lyallii, or the Mount Cook buttercup, prefers moist but well-drained soil. It requires regular watering during its growing season, especially in dry conditions, but care should be taken to avoid waterlogging as it can cause root rot. Ensure the soil remains consistently damp, particularly during the spring and summer months when the plant is actively growing. During the dormant period in winter, reduce watering to prevent soggy soil conditions. Using mulch can help maintain soil moisture, but the mulch should not be placed directly against the stem to avoid rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ranunculus lyallii thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of sunlight per day. In climates with intense afternoon sun, providing some light afternoon shade can help to protect the plant from excessive heat and sun scorch. While providing enough light is crucial for robust flowering and growth, care should be taken to ensure the plant does not dry out in very sunny spots. A location with morning sun and afternoon shade often provides the optimal balance for health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ranunculus lyallii involves removing dead or damaged leaves and spent flowers to encourage healthy growth and prevent disease. This plant does not require extensive pruning but benefits from regular maintenance to remove any foliage that may have been damaged by pests or environmental factors. In late autumn, after the plant has finished flowering, it is advisable to cut back any dead flower stalks. However, avoid cutting back healthy foliage excessively as the leaves continue to store nutrients that can be used for the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mount Cook lily","description":"Ranunculus lyallii (Mountain buttercup, Mount Cook buttercup, or, although not a lily, Mount Cook lily), is a species of Ranunculus (buttercup), endemic to New Zealand, where it occurs in the South Island and on Stewart Island at altitudes of 700–1,500 m.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Mount Cook lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Ranunculus lyallii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18707,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hoheria sexstylosa, commonly known as Lacebark Tree, prefers a moderate watering regime. Ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which the roots are particularly sensitive to. During the growing season in spring and summer, water the plant thoroughly once a week. In hotter, drier periods, increase watering frequency to twice a week. In contrast, reduce watering during the fall and winter months when the plant's growth slows. Always check the top layer of soil before watering; it should be dry to the touch to avoid overwatering. Mulching can help retain moisture during dry spells."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hoheria sexstylosa thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It prefers conditions where it can receive at least six hours of direct sunlight per day, which encourages robust flowering and healthy growth. However, in regions with intense summer heat, a location with some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. While the plant can tolerate partial shade, too much shade may lead to reduced flowering and leggier growth. Ensure it is planted in a spot where it can receive ample light but is shielded from the harsh midday sun if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hoheria sexstylosa is essential to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. Prune the plant in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Start by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Next, thin out any crowded areas to increase air circulation, which helps prevent diseases. Cut back overly long branches to maintain the desired shape and size of the tree. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant. Light annual pruning will suffice to keep the Lacebark Tree looking its best and promote a healthy structure."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"long-leaved lacebark","description":"Hoheria sexstylosa (long-leaved lacebark or ribbonwood) is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae, endemic to New Zealand. It is an evergreen tree or shrub growing to 8 m (26 ft) tall by 6 m (20 ft) broad with glossy green leaves, and white flowers in summer and autumn. This tree tends to have a weeping graceful habit and is sometimes sold by nurseries with the name graceful lacebark. The Latin term sexstylosa means \"six styles\".","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["long-leaved lacebark"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Hoheria sexstylosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17997,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Burchellia bubalina prefers moderate watering to maintain its health and vibrancy. During the growing season, which is typically spring through summer, you should water the plant regularly, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. This ensures the plant receives adequate moisture without becoming waterlogged. In the dormant season, reduce the frequency of watering, only providing enough to prevent the soil from becoming completely dry. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has good drainage and the soil is well-aerated."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Burchellia bubalina thrives in bright, indirect sunlight, but it can also tolerate some direct sun, particularly in the morning or late afternoon. If placed indoors, a location near a window that receives plenty of natural light is ideal. While it can withstand short periods of lower light, prolonged exposure to inadequate light conditions can result in reduced flowering and less vibrant foliage. Avoid intense, direct midday sun, which can scorch the leaves. In regions with hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Burchellia bubalina is beneficial for maintaining its shape and encouraging new growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote healthy growth. Additionally, prune to thin out crowded areas, allowing more light and air to reach the inner parts of the plant. Always use clean and sharp pruning tools to prevent disease spread. Be cautious not to remove more than one-third of the plant’s volume at a time to reduce stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wild Pomegranate","description":"Burchellia is a monotypic genus of flowering plants in the Rubiaceae family. The genus contains only one species, viz. Burchellia bubalina, which is endemic to southern Africa: the Cape Provinces, KwaZulu-Natal and the Northern Provinces in South Africa, and Swaziland. It is commonly known as \"wild pomegranate\" (English) or \"wildegranaat\" (Afrikaans).","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Dark green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Wild Pomegranate"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Burchellia bubalina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18906,"attracts":["Birds","Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Nuxia floribunda, also known as Forest Elder, prefers regular watering, especially in the growing season, to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Ensure the plant has good drainage to prevent root rot, as it dislikes standing water. During the cooler months or dormancy periods, reduce watering to allow the top inch of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and promote healthy growth. It's important to adjust watering frequency based on local climate conditions and the specific microenvironment of the plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nuxia floribunda thrives in full sun to partial shade. It blooms best in locations where it receives plenty of sunlight, ideally at least 6 hours of direct sun daily. However, it can also tolerate semi-shade conditions, particularly in hotter climates where some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. If planted under full sun in very hot or dry regions, additional watering and mulching may be necessary to preserve soil moisture and protect the roots. Ensure that the plant is gradually accustomed to higher light levels to prevent sunburn on the leaves."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Nuxia floribunda is usually done to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before the new growth starts. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to promote healthy growth. Additionally, selectively trim back overcrowded areas to enhance air circulation within the canopy. Light pruning throughout the growing season can also help stimulate flowering. Ensure to use clean, sharp tools to minimize damage and reduce the risk of infection. Regular pruning can also help manage its size if space is limited."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Forest Elder","description":"Nuxia floribunda, the forest elder, forest nuxia or wild elder, is a species of tree in the Stilbaceae family, that is native to moist regions of southern Africa, East Africa and central tropical Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Forest Elder"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Nuxia floribunda"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17697,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Symphytum caucasicum, commonly known as Caucasian comfrey, prefers consistently moist soil but does not fare well in waterlogged conditions. It is crucial to keep the soil damp, especially during the flowering and growing seasons in spring and summer. Water it thoroughly when the top inch of soil feels dry, allowing any excess water to drain away completely. During the dormant winter period, reduce watering frequency as the plant requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Symphytum caucasicum thrives in partial to full shade, making it suitable for woodland gardens or shaded areas in a landscape. While it can tolerate some morning sun, it generally prefers protection from harsh afternoon sunlight which might scorch the leaves. Bright, indirect light in the morning followed by shaded conditions later in the day offers an ideal environment for optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Symphytum caucasicum involves removing dead or damaged leaves and stems to keep the plant healthy and promote vigorous growth. It is best to prune after the flowering period, usually in late autumn. Cut back the flower stalks to prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively and to tidy its appearance. Regular removal of yellowing or faded leaves will encourage new growth and maintain plant vitality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Caucasian Comfrey","description":"Symphytum caucasicum, the beinwell, blue comfrey, or Caucasian comfrey, is an ornamental plant of Symphytum genus in the Boraginaceae family, which is native to Caucasus.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Caucasus","Turkey"],"other_name":["Caucasian Comfrey"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Symphytum caucasicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19107,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Myriopteris lindheimeri, also known as the Lindheimer's cloak fern, prefers well-drained soil and should be watered moderately. During its growing season in spring and summer, ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not waterlogged. Reduce watering during the fall and winter when the plant enters its dormant period, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to check soil moisture levels regularly. Also, using room temperature water helps to avoid shocking the plant's root system."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Myriopteris lindheimeri thrives in partial shade to full shade conditions. It naturally grows under trees or in rock crevices, where it receives filtered light. Aim to provide it with indirect or dappled sunlight, as direct exposure, especially in hot afternoon sun, can scorch the fronds and lead to dehydration. If grown indoors, place it near a north or east-facing window. If the plant appears to be stretching or the fronds are losing color, it may be receiving too little light, in which case it can be moved to a brighter spot."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Myriopteris lindheimeri should be done minimally, primarily to remove any dead or damaged fronds, which can be carefully cut back to the base of the plant. This encourages healthy new growth and maintains the plant's appearance. It is best to prune during the plant's dormant period in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Make sure to use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant or spreading disease. Removing old fronds can also improve air circulation around the plant, reducing disease risk."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lindheimer's lipfern","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Lindheimer's lipfern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Myriopteris lindheimeri"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17404,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Yucca gigantea, also known as the Spineless Yucca, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires infrequent watering. Allow the top couple of inches of soil to dry out thoroughly between waterings. Water deeply but less frequently, which is generally every two to three weeks, depending on light and temperature conditions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has proper drainage and never let the plant sit in water. In winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant enters a period of dormancy and requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Yucca gigantea thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can also handle some direct sun exposure. Ideally, place the plant in a spot that gets plenty of natural light, such as near southeast or south-facing windows. While it can adapt to moderate light conditions, it will not grow as vigorously in low light. If growing outside, ensure it has enough space and light, while being sheltered from harsh midday sunlight in hot climates, as this can cause leaf burn. Rotate the plant occasionally to encourage even growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Yucca gigantea is necessary to remove dead or damaged leaves and to maintain an attractive shape. Prune in the spring just before the plant's growth spurt. Remove any yellow, brown, or damaged leaves by cutting them off at the base. For taller plants, you can trim the tops of the stems to control height, which also encourages branching and a fuller appearance. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent infection and make clean cuts. Wearing gloves is advisable due to the plant's sharp leaf tips and possible sap irritation."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Spineless Yucca","description":"Yucca gigantea (syn. Yucca elephantipes, Yucca guatemalensis), is a Yucca species that is native to Belize, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and the eastern part of Mexico (Quintana Roo, Yucatán, Campeche, Tabasco, Chiapas, Veracruz, eastern Puebla and southern Tamaulipas). It is also reportedly naturalized in Puerto Rico, the Leeward Islands and Ecuador.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Spineless Yucca"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Scale insects","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Yucca gigantea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17302,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Aglaia odorata, commonly known as the Chinese Perfume Plant, prefers moderate watering. The soil should be kept consistently moist but never soggy. During the growing season (spring to early autumn), water the plant regularly to encourage healthy growth and blooming. Allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. In the winter months, reduce watering frequency, letting the soil dry out slightly more between waterings as the plant's growth slows down. Always ensure that the pot has proper drainage to prevent waterlogging."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aglaia odorata thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct sun, preferably morning sun, but too much direct afternoon sun can scorch its leaves. If growing indoors, place it near a south or east-facing window where it can receive plenty of filtered light. If natural light is limited, this plant can adapt to fluorescent lighting, making it suitable for indoor environments like offices. Ensure to rotate the plant regularly to promote even growth, preventing it from leaning towards a single light source."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aglaia odorata is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging bushier growth. It is best done in the spring. Lightly prune the plant to remove any dead, damaged, or weak branches to stimulate new growth. Trimming the tips of the branches can promote denser foliage and more profuse flowering. Avoid heavy pruning as it can stress the plant. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent inflicting damage or causing infection. Regular trimming will help the plant maintain a compact and lush appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Chinese Perfume Plant","description":"Aglaia odorata is a species of plant in the family Meliaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18708,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hoheria angustifolia requires moderate watering. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist, especially during its growing season in spring and summer. However, care should be taken to avoid waterlogging, as this can lead to root rot. Water the plant deeply once the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. During fall and winter, reduce watering to allow the plant to rest, ensuring you only water enough to keep the soil from becoming completely dry. Always use well-draining soil to help prevent excess moisture retention."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hoheria angustifolia thrives best in a location with full sun to partial shade. It prefers receiving at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to support its growth and flowering. If planted in an area that gets too much shade, it may not flower as profusely and could become leggy. While it can tolerate some shade, ensuring it receives adequate sunlight helps maintain a healthy and robust plant structure. In very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and ensure the plant remains healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hoheria angustifolia is best done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve airflow and maintain the shrub’s shape. Thin out overcrowded branches to ensure light penetrates to the lower leaves. Avoid heavy pruning, as this might stress the plant. Instead, aim for gradual shaping over several seasons. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to minimize injury to the plant, and avoid pruning too late in the season to allow time for new growth to harden off before winter."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Narrow-leaved lacebark","description":"Hoheria angustifolia, the narrow-leaved lacebark or narrow-leaved houhere, is a species of flowering plant in the family Malvaceae, endemic to New Zealand.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["New Zealand"],"other_name":["Narrow-leaved lacebark"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Hoheria angustifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17998,"attracts":["Butterflies","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cornus racemosa, commonly known as gray dogwood, prefers moist, well-drained soils but can tolerate a variety of conditions once established. Water young plants regularly to help them establish a deep root system. For mature specimens, provide water during prolonged dry spells, especially during hot summer months. The soil should remain moist, but not waterlogged, as overly wet conditions can lead to root rot. In areas with frequent rainfall, additional irrigation may be unnecessary. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain an even temperature around the roots. Overall, gray dogwood is quite adaptable to diverse moisture conditions once it's established."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cornus racemosa thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. For optimal growth and flowering, provide at least four to six hours of direct sunlight per day. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch and mitigate the stress of excessive heat. However, in cooler regions, more sun exposure could enhance blooming and foliage color. Positioning the plant in a location that provides morning sun and afternoon shade can strike a good balance. Its adaptable nature also means it can grow under a variety of light conditions, though more sun does typically yield the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cornus racemosa should be conducted in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This timing helps to maintain the plant's shape and encourages healthy, vigorous growth. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to keep the shrub healthy. Thinning out some of the older stems at the base will increase air circulation and allow more light into the center of the plant. For aesthetic shaping, trim branches as needed to maintain the desired form. Regular pruning helps foster better flowering and fruiting while preventing it from becoming overly dense and unkempt."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"gray dogwood","description":"Cornus racemosa, the northern swamp dogwood, gray dogwood or panicle dogwood, is a shrubby plant native to southeastern Canada and the northeastern United States. It is a member of the dogwood genus Cornus and the family Cornaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern North America"],"other_name":["gray dogwood"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf spot","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cornus racemosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Thinning out crowded areas can improve air circulation within the canopy. When pruning, use sharp, clean tools to make clean cuts and avoid tearing the bark. "},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Tricyrtis formosana involves removing dead or damaged stems and foliage to encourage healthy growth. Watering should be done in a way that keeps the growing substrate (like straw or sawdust) damp but not waterlogged. Spraying the substrate with water regularly or using a humidity tent can assist in maintaining the required moisture levels. It is crucial to avoid letting the substrate dry out, as this could impede mushroom growth. Monitoring the humidity around the plant is key, aiming for a level around 80-90%, which can typically be sustained with periodic misting."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pleurotus citrinopileatus mushrooms thrive in indirect, low to moderate light conditions, as direct sunlight can dry out the growing substrate and damage the delicate tissue of the mushrooms. They naturally grow in shaded areas, such as under forest canopies, so replicating similar conditions indoors is beneficial. Provide a light source that mimics dappled sunlight or use ambient indoor lighting if growing them inside. Ensure they are kept out of direct harsh lights to maintain the necessary humidity and prevent drying, fostering a suitable environment for their development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically relevant for Pleurotus citrinopileatus since it is not a traditional plant but a fungus. Instead of pruning, focus on harvesting mushrooms at the right time. The ideal time to harvest is when the caps are fully opened, but before they start to curl up. Use a clean, sharp knife or twist them gently to remove. Regularly remove any mature mushrooms to encourage new growth and prevent them from rotting, which could invite pests or diseases if left unattended."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Golden Oyster Mushroom","description":"Pleurotus citrinopileatus, the golden oyster mushroom (tamogitake in Japanese), is an edible gilled fungus. Native to eastern Russia, northern China, and Japan, the golden oyster mushroom is very closely related to P. cornucopiae of Europe, with some authors considering them to be at the rank of subspecies. In far eastern Russia, P. citrinopileatus, there called iI'mak, is one of the most popular wild edible mushrooms.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Spring","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Northern Asia","Eastern Europe"],"other_name":["Golden Oyster Mushroom"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Insect infestation"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Pleurotus citrinopileatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18119,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dawsonia superba requires consistent moisture to thrive, mimicking its natural habitat where it typically grows in moist environments. Water the plant regularly to keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged, as excessive water can lead to rot. It is crucial to ensure the planting medium drains well to prevent any standing water. During drier periods, increase watering frequency to compensate for the lack of humidity and natural precipitation. However, in cooler seasons or less active growth phases, reduce watering slightly to avoid over-saturation. Regular misting can also help maintain the necessary high humidity levels for this moss species."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dawsonia superba thrives in low to medium light conditions, replicating the dappled light of its native rainforest habitats. It prefers indirect sunlight when grown indoors, as direct sunlight can cause the delicate tissues of the moss to dry out and become damaged. If grown outside, find a spot that receives partial to full shade. Avoid exposing it to intense, direct midday sun, as this can lead to dehydration and stress. Ensuring the right amount of indirect light will help maintain its lush green appearance and support healthy growth. Adjust its location accordingly to provide optimal lighting conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not commonly needed for Dawsonia superba as it is a moss and does not grow to a size where pruning would be necessary for shape or vigor. However, you may gently remove any brown or dead parts that appear to keep it looking its best and to promote healthy growth. This can usually be done by pinching off the affected areas with your fingers or trimming carefully with scissors. Always ensure any pruning tools are clean to prevent the introduction of diseases. Pruning should be done as needed rather than on a fixed schedule."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"giant moss","description":"Dawsonia superba is a large moss, growing typically to 60 cm in height. It is the tallest self supporting moss in the world, but the vine Spiridens reinwardtii climbs to ten feet (3 meters). On Mount Kinabalu in Malaysian Borneo, Dawsonia superba has been measured to forty inches (1.0 meter) in height.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia","New Zealand"],"other_name":["giant moss"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Dawsonia superba"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid excessive pruning as this species is sensitive to over-cutting."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"White Cheesewood","description":"Alstonia scholaris (commonly called blackboard tree, devil tree, ditabark, milkwood-pine, white cheesewood) is an evergreen tropical tree in the family Apocynaceae. In lower light conditions, the plant may not grow as robustly, and its leaf colors may become less vibrant. This not only encourages new growth but also improves the plant’s overall appearance and health. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the plant. If the plant becomes leggy, cutting back the stems to just above a node can encourage fuller growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19408,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rhamnus humboldtiana, commonly known as Humboldt's buckthorn, requires moderate watering. During the growing season, which spans from spring to early fall, maintain a consistent watering schedule to keep the soil lightly moist, but be careful not to overwater as this can lead to root rot. During the winter months, reduce watering significantly, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. It is generally drought tolerant but will grow more robustly with regular moisture. Always ensure that the plant is in well-draining soil to prevent standing water around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rhamnus humboldtiana thrives in full sun to partial shade. It performs best in environments where it can receive at least six hours of sunlight per day. However, it can tolerate some light shade, which might be beneficial in extremely hot climates to prevent leaf scorch. If grown indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive adequate sunlight. If this plant does not get enough light, it may become leggy and produce fewer leaves, so ensuring appropriate sunlight is critical for healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rhamnus humboldtiana should be done primarily in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This is to manage its size, encourage bushiness or to remove any dead or diseased branches to maintain plant health. Trim back overgrown branches to maintain the desired shape and remove any crossing branches that could lead to damage. Regular pruning will also improve air circulation within the plant, reducing the risk of fungal diseases. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season, as this can stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Coyotillo","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Coyotillo"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Rhamnus humboldtiana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Rust fungi do not undergo processes that require pruning; instead, they can form galls on their host plant, which may impact plant health. Controlling its spread rather than pruning is necessary, usually by removing infected parts of the host plant or using fungicides in agricultural settings. Management often involves targeted removal of affected plant matrices to prevent further spread and infection of the rust."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Uromycladium tepperianum is a rust fungus that infects over 100 species of Acacia and related genera including Paraserianthes in Australia, south-east Asia, the south Pacific and New Zealand. If cultured, avoid excessive handling, as it can damage the delicate structure and inhibit growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18910,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Gymnanthemum amygdalinum, commonly known as Vernonia amygdalina or bitter leaf, requires moderate watering. During the growing season, water the plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Reduce watering in the winter months when the growth slows down. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and maintain the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"This plant thrives in full sunlight to partial shade. Ideally, Gymnanthemum amygdalinum should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth, especially if grown for its medicinal leaves. However, it can tolerate some afternoon shade, especially in very hot climates, to prevent leaf scorch. If cultivating it indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window to ensure it receives adequate light. Supplemental grow lights can also be used if natural light is insufficient."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gymnanthemum amygdalinum helps maintain its shape and promote bushier growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19605,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Searsia lucida is a drought-tolerant plant commonly found in dry, sandy conditions. It requires minimal watering once established. During initial growth, it's crucial to water regularly to promote root development. Once the plant is established, reduce watering to once every couple of weeks. Ensure the soil dries out between waterings to prevent root rot. Be mindful of local climate conditions; in drier, hotter climates, it may need more frequent watering, while in cooler, moist climates, less water is necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Searsia lucida thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal growth, provide it with at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It can tolerate some shade, especially in hotter climates, as long as it receives sufficient light for most of the day. In shaded areas, growth may become more sparse and less vigorous. Adjust the planting site as needed to ensure the plant receives enough light. If grown indoors, position the plant near a south or west-facing window to maximize sunlight exposure. This sunlight is crucial for healthy growth and foliage vibrance."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Searsia lucida should be done lightly to maintain its natural shape and encourage bushiness. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or diseased branches to improve air circulation and prevent disease. It's also beneficial to thin out crowded branches to enhance sunlight penetration. Prune away overlapping branches to allow for better growth, but avoid over-pruning as this can stress the plant. Searsia lucida generally does not require heavy pruning due to its naturally tidy growth habit."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Glossy Currantrhus","description":"Searsia lucida, previously known as Rhus lucida, and other names varnished kuni-rhus (English) blinktaaibos (Afrikaans). Its distribution area also encompasses the whole of Kwazulu-Natal and stretches in an arm past Swaziland, right up the Lowveld areas of Mpumalanga and into Limpopo Province, almost to the Zimbabwe border....","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Glossy Currantrhus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Searsia lucida"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the growing season in spring and summer, ensure the soil remains consistently moist but not saturated. Reduce watering in the fall and winter months when the plant is not actively growing. It's advisable to water deeply and less frequently to encourage deep root development. A well-draining soil mix will help prevent root rot by allowing excess water to drain away. Water when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solanum laciniatum thrives in a location with full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight per day for the best growth and flowering. In regions with exceptionally hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch. In more temperate or cooler climates, full sun will promote vigorous growth. Ensuring the plant receives adequate light is crucial for flowering and fruiting. If growing indoors, place it near a south-facing window or provide supplemental lighting to mimic natural sunlight conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solanum laciniatum should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This will help maintain a healthy shape and encourage bushier growth. Remove any dead or damaged branches and thin out the center of the plant to improve air circulation. Avoid cutting more than a third of the plant at any one time to prevent shock. Regular pruning will help control the size and spread of the plant, as it can grow quite rapidly. When pruning, use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"kangaroo-apple","description":"Solanum laciniatum is a soft-wooded shrub native to the east coast of Australia, notably Victoria and Tasmania. During fall and winter, reduce watering significantly, as the plant enters a dormancy period where it requires much less moisture. Always ensure the pot has drainage holes, and never let the plant sit in water to ensure healthy root development and prevent fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Roldana petasitis thrives best in a location that receives partial to full sunlight. It enjoys bright, indirect light but can also tolerate some direct sunlight, particularly morning sun, which is less intense. However, in very hot climates, it is essential to provide some protection from the harsh afternoon sun to prevent leaf scorching. When grown indoors as a houseplant, place it near a window where it can receive ample light or supplement with a grow light to ensure it flourishes. Consistent light conditions will support its lush growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Roldana petasitis is an essential practice to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. It’s best to prune this plant in early spring before the new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged stems and cut back any overly long shoots to encourage denser foliage. Regular pruning helps manage the size of the plant and stimulates new growth. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and avoid causing damage to the plant tissue. Sanitizing tools before use can help prevent the spread of diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"velvet groundsel","description":"Roldana petasitis also known as velvet groundsel is a species of the genus Roldana and family Asteraceae that used to be a Senecio.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["velvet groundsel"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Slugs"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Roldana petasitis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17002,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Silphium gracile, commonly known as the slender rosinweed, requires moderate watering. During the growing season, water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry. Ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent water from accumulating around the roots. In winter, reduce watering frequency significantly as the plant enters its dormant phase and requires less moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Silphium gracile thrives in full sun conditions and requires a minimum of six hours of direct sunlight daily. It is a prairie plant and adapted to open, sunny environments. Planting it in full sun ensures robust flowering and overall health. While it can tolerate partial shade, lack of sufficient sunlight might lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms. Make sure to position it in a location where it won't be overshadowed by taller plants or structures, maximizing its exposure to sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Silphium gracile involves cutting back the plant to manage its shape and promote healthy growth. Deadheading spent flowers can encourage blooming and prevent self-seeding, which helps maintain its structure in a garden setting. Prune in late fall or early spring before new growth begins, cutting back to a height of about 6-12 inches. This also helps to remove any dead or diseased stems. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and minimize stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Slender Rosinweed","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Slender Rosinweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Silphium gracile"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19112,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dichopogon strictus, commonly known as chocolate lily, prefers well-drained soils and requires moderate watering. It is important to ensure that the soil does not become waterlogged, as this can lead to root rot. During the growing season, water the plant when the topsoil appears dry, approximately every 7 to 10 days. In the winter months or dormant periods, reduce watering significantly to prevent excessive moisture in the soil, which is sufficient to sustain the plant until active growth restarts in spring."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dichopogon strictus thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to ensure healthy growth and flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, it may result in reduced flowering. In areas with extremely hot climates, afternoon shade can help prevent the plant from becoming scorched and conserve soil moisture. Thus, choosing a location with ample morning sunlight and some afternoon shade is optimal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Dichopogon strictus is not usually necessary, as it is a low-maintenance plant. However, removing dead or wilted flowers, commonly known as deadheading, can encourage further blooming and maintain the plant's aesthetic appeal by preventing the plant from expending energy on seed production. Trim back any dead foliage at the beginning of autumn to prepare the plant for the colder months. Care should be taken to avoid cutting new growth while pruning."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"chocolate lily","description":"Dichopogon strictus (syn. Arthropodium strictum), commonly known as chocolate lily, is a herbaceous perennial plant species native to Australia.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["chocolate lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Dichopogon strictus"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":19308,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oxalis depressa prefers the soil to be kept lightly moist, especially during its active growing season in spring and summer. Water the plant when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. It's crucial to avoid overwatering as it can lead to root rot. During the dormant winter period, reduce watering significantly as the plant requires less moisture when it is not actively growing. Ensure proper drainage in the pot to prevent water from sitting at the bottom."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oxalis depressa thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate some direct sunlight, particularly in the morning or late afternoon, but mid-day sun can scorch its leaves. If indoors, placing it near a window that receives filtered light is ideal. If grown outdoors, slightly shaded areas or spots with dappled sunlight are perfect to protect it from the harshest rays. Insufficient light can cause the plant to grow leggy and weak, so ensure it gets plenty of bright light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Oxalis depressa is minimal, but it helps to remove any dead or yellowing leaves to promote healthier growth and improve the plant's overall appearance. Regularly inspect the plant for any damaged or diseased foliage and trim them with clean scissors. This plant does not require heavy pruning, but light maintenance encourages new growth and maintains a tidy appearance. It's best to perform pruning during the active growing season to stimulate further development."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Early Sorrel","description":"Oxalis depressa is an Oxalis species found in South Africa.
